urn:contentItem:7VWC-0550-Y8Y1-70RC-00000-00CMS Energy Corp. at Citi Power and Utility Conference - Final2009-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:00ZLexisNexis060409a2250368.768CMS Energy Corp. at Citi Power and Utility Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* James Judge NSTAR- CFO, SVP, Treasurer * Mark Ruelle Westar Energy - CFO, EVP * James Scilacci Edison International- CFO, EVP, Treasurer * Robert Hoglund Consolidated Edison - CFO, SVP * John Russell Consumers Energy - President and CEO

Presentation

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Here for our next panel, managing regulatory risk in a recessionary environment, and we are fortunate to have with us a variety of different panelists and executives from some of the top regulated entities in the country. Joined by CMS Energy's John Russell, Consolidated Edison's Robert Hoglund, Edison Internationals' Jim Scilacci, NSTAR's Jim Judge, and Westar's Mark Ruelle. And gentlemen, thank you very much for attending, and hopefully the conference has been helpful for you. It certainly has been for us so far.

On the topic of managing regulatory risk, when we look about how regulators are reacting in this current economic cycle, probably the biggest question I have is, are you seeing the regulators recognizing the cost of capital is a lot higher, has been a lot higher, and have you found the regulators to be accommodating of that environment? Can each of you discuss what the regulator perspective has been and how your relationship with regulators has changed in the current environment? And Jim, if we could start with you.

JAMES JUDGE, CFO, SVP, TREASURER, NSTAR: Sure, at NSTARwe're in a somewhat unique position because we entered into a seven-year rate dale in late 2005, and part of that rate deal was an allowed (inaudible) that was considered up to 12.5% before we share with customers. So we really aren't in a rate case mode where cost of capital is being discussed. I know there's a number of utilities, I think a record number of rate cases filed in the third quarter of last year, 21 rate cases I think in the industry.

So I'm sure there's a lot of discussion and controversy over what the appropriate allowed hours (inaudible) are these days, and especially in light of the interest rate environment. But from my perspective, I've seen about a 10.25, 10.5 allowed hour [week] even though the utilities have been (inaudible).

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Okay, Mark?

MARK RUELLE, CFO, EVP, WESTAR ENERGY: Well, we just settled a rate case in November and it settled with a higher ROE than we had at, for accounting purposes it was pegged at 10.4 even though it wasn't particularly specified, which at the time of our negotiations looked pretty good for us. It was a little bit of an increase. Obviously since then with the market fall off, we believed cost of capital is significantly higher than that. Our regulators seem to appreciate that if not for our benefit having just settled a case, another utility in the state was in the middle of a case, and in fact the staff recommendation came out higher than what was in the utility's application.

So there is a growing appreciation for the importance of understanding that you can't take care of customers unless you also take care of the investors, and both of those parties have to be treated fairly.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Jim?

JAMES SCILACCI, CFO, EVP, TREASURER, EDISON INTERNATIONAL: In California, we have a cost of capital mechanism that's currently set at 11.5% term common equity and we have a unique arrangement for 2010 that the cost of capital will only change based on the movement of the Moody's Baa index. And it's tracking right now that the cost of capital could increase based on an annual move of that index. So we'll have to wait and see what happens. I think generally regulators recognize that things are different. We just got our rate case approved in the first quarter of this year. A lot of consternation about that. I think generally the regulators were concerned that they wanted us to spend money because they look at it as a stimulus program, and they do recognize that maintaining high and efficient cost of capitals are important in terms of having healthy utilities.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: And on that very specific relation that you have with the Moody's Bond Yield, so my understanding is that there's a question of whether it's a A or a Moody's Baa level, and you guys have filed for a Baa level of yields. Can you talk through any indications you may have had from the CPUC as to whether they're going to look at one version or another? How are they responding to your proposal to look at it from a Baa perspective?

JAMES SCILACCI: Well, I think in our case it's very clear it's the Baa index. They've approved that mechanism, so we have clarity around what might happen there.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Okay, great. Robert?

ROBERT HOGLUND, CFO, SVP, CONSOLIDATED EDISON: So, I'm going to pick up both of the moving parts of the capitalization for Consolidated Edison. On the fixed income side, rates have come up for us. I suspect they have for most, although the last couple months they've been coming back down. The commission did something a little out of the ordinary for us in this last round, but we are trued up on interest rates, both taxable and tax-exempt. So no exposure on interest rates, which I suppose you could read either way, but at least we're covered.

On the equity side, we're in a serious of rate cases and all of our services. So when Jim said 23 cases, my guess is we've got a handful of those. So the commission is getting a pretty regular look at cost of capital. Their methodology is pretty prescriptive and I think they would argue is highly reflective of the marginal cost of capital for utilities, discounted cash flow, or what I would call a dividend discount model and a capital asset pricing model. May or may not be happy with the particular inputs that they chose, but methodologically speaking for the marginal cost of capital is pretty transparent to what's going on in the markets.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Okay, actually on that question, Robert, in the last rate decision that was handed down, you and I spoke a little bit earlier about some of the austerity measures that were handed down. I know that that's separate from the cost of capital question. But was it your sense at all that the commission's view towards those, what I believe you position as arbitrary reductions, was that related to the fact that the cost of capital was extremely high, in your opinion? Any sense on that?

ROBERT HOGLUND: No, I don't think so. If you look at the trend in regulatory decisions in New York, the last couple of years the rates have been between, I don't know, 9.7 and 9.1, 2006, '07, and '08, and this year in the decisions that have come before the commissioner that they've approved, the returns have been between 10 to 10.3, 10.4. So the dollars at stake in that range, 115, 120 basis points average I think is relatively small. That's not a significant customer impact. I think the O&M reductions were really more a straw in the wind read on the part of the commission on the economic environment, and more specifically the political implications of the economic environment.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: I see, and John, your thoughts on the regulatory environment cost of capital?

JOHN RUSSELL, PRESIDENT AND CEO, CONSUMERS ENERGY: In Michigan, we have two pending rate cases both in electric and gas. I think the Michigan Public Service Commission understands the correlation between the cost of capital and the return on equity that we need to move forward. I think Michigan is particularly disadvantaged in the way the economy is going in Michigan is going today. So I think they're more aware of it and heightened towards that need. Cases of looking at 10.7%, 11% return on equity, which right now for regular, routine cases, as far as we're concerned that seems reasonable.

So I think they do understand it and part of it comes with education too, whether it's formulistic or whether it comes with understanding the markets, I think that's the responsibility we have to help the commission understand how these work.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Right, well on a secondary subject along that train of thought, are you seeing that regulators are much more willing to be constructive with you in order to maintain and investment grade credit rating? It would seem to us that in this type of environment, they want to make sure, they should want to make sure that your investment grade credit rating isn't in any way threatened by what's going on in the credit markets. Can you talk about that thought pattern? What are you seeing with the regulators? Are you seeing them be more constructive with you or potentially more dilutive to you? And where do you think things are going to go from here? Jim?

JAMES JUDGE: Yes, as I say, we're not really in the rate environment because we have a -- we still have, in the middle I guess of a seven-year rate (inaudible), but I can say that we have an eight plus credit. You go to EEI's website and the list of 58 utilities, we have the strongest credit rating in the industry. And what better testament than last year in terms of the importance of that. The capital markets were in turmoil. We were issuing commercial paper uninterrupted.

We issued $100 million earlier this year (inaudible) money that had a four in front of it. It was under 5% and I think if you had a DDD plus credit or worse, you're looking at 200 or 300 basis points beyond that. So that's millions of dollars more that rate case would pay over time in terms of cost of service because the credit rating had been weaker. So I feel great about the fact that obviously we have a strong credit quality right now, but even more likely that (inaudible) the regulators in Massachusetts, it's credible to maintain going forward.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Mark?

MARK RUELLE: There seems to be a keen understanding, probably even a closer understanding than in the cost of equity with regard to the importance of maintaining credit ratings in Kansas. We're not in the traditional general rate case mode right now, but I think it's fair to say the staff and the commission have an appreciation for the importance of credit ratings. Having said that, the commission and the commission staff has not been particularly prescriptive on those issues in terms of the amount of equity in the capital structure, so long as it's within a reasonable zone. I think Kansas regulators, if there's an appropriate trust between the management and the regulators, they allow management to manage the company and its capital structure as it sees fit.

If we were to do something outside of the normal range, we have no doubt that they would exercise their authority and demonstrate their opinions more forcefully. But we haven't put them in that situation, I think they trust that we'll manage our company responsibly with an eye toward keeping the cost of capital low as a portion of the cost of service.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: I see. I see. Actually, Jim, on this question about investment grade credit ratings, I was talking with one of your peers elsewhere in the industry, and the comment that they were making was, when you run an integrated utility and you are pursuing any type of strategic options with the merchant generation fleet, your flexibility to pursue options is constrained by the fact that you have to also watch what the credit rating agencies say and do about your rating.

And the argument was that it actually makes more inherent business sense to separate merchant agendas as for purely regulated business, because otherwise you just got to bed through too many hoops. What would you say to that view? Does it make sense, or do you actually think that the considerations you have to give to a credit rating agency aren't that onerous that an integrated utility business model actually can work out just fine?

JAMES SCILACCI: Well, I think we all have stories about dealing with the credit rating agencies and how much credit you give to them in terms of their theories. And I struggle at times with some of the mechanisms that a few of the rating agencies have and their logic for how they determine particular notching from the holding company, to the operating companies, to the merchant generation. Those are fairly difficult standards you have to work with, and you can go into arguments about that equivalence and the impact it might have on your balance sheet.

But I think it's important overall from a rate making perspective that there's no perceived preference or support given to the non-utility side. And if there's an action that if your merchant generation falls, if the credit rating of a merchant generator falls and somehow effects the holding company, than indirectly pulls down the utility, I think that would be perceived to be bad. A familiar question is how you fit all these pieces together.

I think we've been able to maneuver over time that we've got the best of both worlds because we've seen both sides of the business being up and down, and it wasn't too long ago when we had to ring fence our merchant generation company from our utility because our utility was declining in credit quality precipitously during the California energy crisis. Now, we're probably flipped all the way around now. We're -- EME is struggling and FC is having a good run.

So having both sides of the business we think is the right way to go. You have to watch the credit rating issues because I don't want to have any kind of perception that the utility is in any way supporting the non-utility side.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: When I was having a discussion with Ted Kramer not too long ago --

JAMES SCILACCI: Oh, is that the guy you were talking to?

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Maybe. One of the points that he brought up was that it was adamant they get across to the credit rating agencies and the regulators that there would be no external, or there would be no extra support given to EME from the parent and the regulated utility, SoCalEd. Have you found the credit rating agencies and the regulators asking you or more concerned about that question? Or do you feel that -- or have you not seen that crop up as an issue?

JAMES SCILACCI: No, we go through those conversations with really the rating agencies. We have very clear and deliberate affiliate roles in the state. You must follow those or you don't even go up to the line on those. So that's clear. There's not much discussion with your regulators on those. So with the rating agencies, we spent a lot of times trying to tell them about the protections the utility has in the state vis-a-vis how dollars can move up to the holding company and how dollars may flow down the non-utility side. And you get into a very extensive debates about the rigor of those protections and what might happen should the non-utility side get in distress.

Those are your really hot debate points, and I think to a certain degree one of the rating agencies is very locked into their structure, how they like to see separations, and how much they're willing to see between the operating companies and the holding company. And those are ongoing debates right now. A couple of rating agencies are looking at the credit rating of Edison Mission Energy as a result of cash flows being substantially reduced because the power prices are down.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Last question on this.

JAMES SCILACCI: I get another one?

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: One more with you, Jim. I've seen a lot of investors comment that the implied value of Mission in Edison's share price can be in the negative side right now, depending on how you value SoCalEd. And I dare say that that's actually the investor consensus right now. What sort of steps do you think can be taken over the next 12 months to help show that that may not be the right way to look at the shares, or that there is some hidden value there beyond waiting for economic recovery or gas prices to rise, something outside of your control.

JAMES SCILACCI: I think I've had this question a few times, even today. I think it's illogical that EME could trade for a negative value. It just doesn't make much sense. When you look at the components of Edison International, there's the big utility and there's non-utility side, and you've got a good comp in terms of PG&E in terms of how it trades, and how SCE should trade. So you can value SCE fairly easily, and to the extent, after you adjust for some minimum amount of holding company dreg, you can figure out what the value of EME, EIX should be.

So we go through the process of talking with people, and I challenge people try to arb out that difference, because it seems like it's money on the table. And a lot of people understand that belief, and getting value out of EME is really an option on the commodity cycle. If we get the commodity cycle, if you get to the recovery point, I think EME ultimately will have value. It's got some environmental challenges and we're working through those issues too, but it's an ongoing process reminding folks what the facts are and I think ultimately you'll see some value there.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Okay, great.

JAMES SCILACCI: Going to ask some other questions?

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: I think we're good. Robert and John, one of the things that we have been curious about is, do you see that in this higher cost of capital environment the regulators are a little bit less willing to allow past through for big ticket items? Are you finding yourself having to be a little bit more judicious in terms of what you ask for in terms of investment?

JOHN RUSSELL: I don't think they're resistant to big ticket items, as long as a big ticket items are communicated with them, that there's a value that the customers receive from that, and it's something of interest to that. And so, the big difference is if we're going to build a power plant or we're going to move forward with renewable energy, it's something that they want to have happen. If they're opposed to a new coal plant or opposed to renewable energy optimization, then yes, we're going to meet resistance based on that.

But it helps and we've done it in Michigan where you've changed -- you've adopted energy legislation that enables us to move forward on a certainty basis. So we know what we're investing in, the cost of investments so we can move it forward. So if the commission was opposed to something, I'd think, yes, they're going to tell you that and make it very difficult, particularly for the big tech guys.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Is there any big disagreement between you and the commission between what you think needs to be done over the long run and what -- ?

JOHN RUSSELL: What is what in the long -- ?

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Is there a big difference in opinion between what you think needs to be done over the long run versus what they think needs to be done in the long run?

JOHN RUSSELL: No, I don't think so. I mean, I think part of it is the way to get to the end we may debate, is it best to go, think of a balanced portfolio, is it best to do it with nuclear, with new clean coal or renewables. I think at that point you need to align and say we can get there by this standard. The thing that we need both from the regulators and what was incorporated into the law in Michigan is certainty, and it's clear to have that certainty, many of us on the electric side of the business are concerned about the uncertainty of the rules that are going on with a mission controls today.

I'd rather have certainty, reasonable certainty so we can move forward and build, and that's what we've done in Michigan with the law, a standard for renewable energy, a standard for energy optimization, a process that if you build a big ticket item you can go through a certificate of necessity process to ensure that that has been fully vetted and approved for the future. And with the type of big ticket items we're talking about, I think other are here, you want to ensure you have that certainty so you can make the investment.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: How about in New York?

ROBERT HOGLUND: A little harder to answer the question for New York because we don't really have a big ticket item. The utilities in the state are effectively out of the production business. We have a steam business, the biggest steam business in the world, but it's still, it's like 1.4 billion of rate base. So it's not that big. But I'd second what John said, which I think is, as long as the regulator is in agreement with the purpose of the spend, the purpose of the spend is not the issue.

The Public Service Commission when they approved rates for us in April approved more than half a billion dollar increase that comes on top of a $425 million increase the year before. There aren't really big projects in that increase, but the amount of dollars that they're approving, and that was, I think we got $5.25 million this time plus $200 million in a tax recovery.

So almost three-quarters of a $1 billion in increase to the end use customer, and they were willing to sign off on that. So that's a pretty big bite. But it's because they like the discrete pieces that they see in that proposal or they don't actively dislike them. And they're more than happy to add to the bill.

So a renewable portfolio standard, sure, put another couple $100 million onto that. You want solar, yes, we'll put another $50 million to $100 million onto that. You want energy efficiency programs funded by the state, sure, we'll put another $50 million or $100 million on that. So they don't seem to shy away from loading the bill up as long as they agree with what the money's being spent on.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: I think even in this economic environment, they seem to be fairly constructive.

ROBERT HOGLUND: I think, and again it's the education that John talked about. To the extent that they understand what the issues are and they agree with the spend, they're willing to go along. Now, that's not without some complaining, but the dollars that are being pushed through to the customer, pretty substantial.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: (inaudible) opinion, is that a fair statement that generally you and the regulators seem to be in agreement on some either big ticket items or large CapEx spend?

MARK RUELLE: I think so. I mean, fundamentally, and I don't know why people have to be reminded of this every so often, but because it's so true is the jobs of the utility management and the jobs of the regulators are not that dissimilar. The mission, I mean, is not that dissimilar. You need -- everyone wants safe, reliable service at a reasonable price and in order to get that you'd have to be fair with the people that provide the capital for that business. And I think in Kansas, we are in a situation where it's constructive, and collaborative, and transparent, and they understand that.

So for example, for Westar some of the big ticket items are pollution controls on our coal plants, and a few years ago we went and explained to the regulators and the staff what was involved with that. They understand that issue and in fact they have allowed us to have an environmental cost recovery rider that addresses the return on that investment and the return of, i.e. depreciation on that investment without having to go through the inefficiencies, and the time lag, and the uncertainties, as well as just the cost of doing a rate case for such a single big ticket item. That's been in place now for three or four years. In fact, just this week on Monday we adjusted a sizeable adjustment to reflect the pollution control equipment we put in place last year. We increased our prices $32 million a year on Monday, and they understand what that's about. The consumer advocate even understands. Nobody likes to raise the prices, including us, but they understand it.

Similar, because of where we sit with regard to the opportunities for renewable energy and the tacit understanding that renewable energy without a transmission system makes no sense. Our legislature and endorsed through the commission by its action has allowed to adjust our prices for our transmission costs and service. So in fact, the Kansas Corporation Commission no longer makes the detailed rate setting on transmission. That's done at the FERC through a formula rate and then there's a rider on our retail build that just mirrors the change in that formula rate for the transmission cost of service. Now, not everything in the transmission cost of service is a big ticket item, but it is one of the areas where we're probably growing more progressively for the obvious reasons I think.

So those two big components of our cost of service, the regulators clearly understand what that is. They understand the importance of having timely and adequate rate recovery on that, and in fact have carved them out of the cost of service in a general rate case sort of way. So we are very conscious of what it means to raise prices on customers, particularly in a soft economy and we wouldn't quite view it the same way, Robert, that you said maybe your regulators are viewing it. We don't want to see our prices increase. So we do things to keep those price increases minimal and I think our regulators do as well.

So for example, when the cost of capital started shooting up, we cut back our construction budget. It's not because we couldn't raise that capital. It's because we don't want to raise that capital in a way that's dilutive and neither do we want to raise our prices to our customers at a time when they may be having a harder time paying for it.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Well, on that topic, and I think it's fortunate that we have four CFOs on the panel as well, although John I'll ask for your opinion on this too. We've seen it in the past, when an economic cyclical downturn occurs, a lot of your peers will have capital expenditures that are fairly high. They'd limit up the balance sheet a little bit and then all of a sudden the economy goes into a downward turn, and wouldn't you know it, in order to protect the credit rating you've got to issue equity.

Now, we've seen a couple of your peers already issue equity. We've seen a couple of rate deals that mandate equity issuances. Where do you think we are from an industry perspective in the cycle of the defense of the utility universe having to issue equity? Have we kind of gotten through the worst of it? Do you think we're still seeing more to come here? What do you think? Jim?

JAMES JUDGE: I guess it's a tough question for me because as I mentioned, we're already an A+, so we don't have any (inaudible) to issue equity to make our credit rating higher. I just think that obviously the tendency around the agencies has been more downgrades than upgrades. So I do think there's some balance sheet repair that needs to go on in the industry. But I feel very good about our cap structure currently. We don't have, like Robert, we don't really have any big ticket items.

We have kind of a maintenance level capital budget. The only big ticket is in the transition budget, which can flex based on projects (inaudible). We're a partner with them on that Hydro Quebec project. So we have some transmission opportunities, but again the balance sheet is strong enough, the cash flow is strong enough that we have no intentions of issuing equity in the near term or the long-term basis.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Mark, your thoughts on where are we in the industry in terms of equity issuances?

MARK RUELLE: Well, I think it's very much a case by case point of view, and I can only speak to Westar's case. We had a very substantial construction program and still do, but scaled much back in light of the more recent events in the capital market. We're a small company. Our market cap's probably $2 billion. We issued over $500 million of equity in 2007 and 2008 and we're pleased to have done so at the time we did. And at the time, people said, well gosh, that's really a lot. You don't need it all right now, but we have a little bit different philosophy in our businesses.

We implicitly acknowledge that we cannot predict the future, and as a result of that it dictates behavior, and for us it has dictated flexibility. And that means you raise capital when it's cheap and you don't spend it and require it when it's (inaudible). And so we were able -- we didn't want to back ourselves in a corner and just hope the capital system was going to be cheap. So we financed our capital program all along the way and raised $500 million, and spent pretty aggressively, but then absolutely pulled in our horns last year when capital costs got so much higher. In our case, that's, I think that has bred trust and goodwill with the ratings agency.

Fitch upgraded us in August. S&P upgraded us on our unsecured rating in November. We just recently went from stable to positive and are not feeling pressure from the ratings agencies to do more. And in large part, that's because the best way to determine when someone's going to do is what they have done, and they've seen us pull in our horns and reduce our capital program, and keep it flexible enough so that we don't back ourselves in a corner and have to raise capital when it's most expensive, and then turn around and have to raise rates when it's maybe most inconvenient and difficult on our customers.

JAMES SCILACCI: At Southern California Edison, it has lots of big projects and tremendous growth, and right now we're seeing growth anywhere from the 10% to 13% compounded annually and rate-based growth. And the biggest swing factor for us in terms of seeing potential equity in our future is, will we have transmission projects built in the timeframe that we currently have filed. And we have seen year-after-year as of late, transmission projects taking longer than we thought possible.

And so what we tried to do for the investing world is show what we think. We tried to give basically a base case and a low case of capital expenditures and the thing that really swings for us in terms of what, if we're on that higher edge versus the lower edge, is when things are at for transmission. And if you ride at the higher edge of the capital expenditures there's a possible need for equity. And at this point in time, clearly we don't want to issue equity in these kind of markets. It's not something that we find attractive at these prices.

We haven't allowed our leverage to increase because the Public Utilities Commission of California mandates a certain equity ratio at 48%. So we have to maintain that. That's the guiding rule. We may put some short-term debt on the balance sheet to defer any kind of need that we might possibly have until the markets are more attractive. So it's the transmission expenditures that really drive the potential need for if we're going to see any equity at Edison International.

ROBERT HOGLUND: Two thoughts. One is, having done this for 15 or 20 years, the financial institutions consistently overestimate the equity need. So I'm always amazed when they come around with their little banker books and they say, God, you got to have 87 trillion dollars worth of equity in this sector. And it never shows up, and it never shows up because I think the math just isn't real clean. The second part which I think is part of the under estimation process is we actually do, as an industry, respond to the economy.

And so there was some very high quality research reports that came out last fall that said CapEx is coming down in the sector. Well, yes, it's going to come down in the sector. You have industrial growth off 20% in the Midwest, you're going to have less CapEx in the Midwest. So we do have sort of a natural hedge in our financing, if you will. If we're responding to what our customers need, we're going to need less when the economy is bad and we're going to need more when the economy is good, and hopefully the economy and that markets don't get too disconnected.

JOHN RUSSELL: I couldn't agree more. The only thing I'll say next, if you ask it from an industry standpoint, we're a very, very capital intensive industry. And the infrastructure we have in place today, regardless of whether you're in a rate freeze or not, is aging. So there will be a lot of investment in this industry when things come back, (inaudible) Robert that they come back, and we're in a position that does well. We're going to have to capitalize the firms to be able to handle that.

So just as an industry, many of reports have us all spending several billion dollars as an industry a year to make this happen. And I think we're going to need to. I mean I think of, particularly in Michigan, if we get electrification of vehicles, that means the distribution opportunity that probably none of us have experience before. The dependency of customers on us not only for their household and their business, but also for their transportation.

And there's a lot of potential investment out there, and if we take the aging infrastructure that we have, and we've got the dubious distinction of having the oldest fossil fleet in the country. So I mean, either we keep that going or we change it and use something different. So I think even though I absolutely agree with your estimates, what we've seen from the banks. We'll be spending some money and we'll need to capitalize (inaudible).

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Thanks, going back to what you were talking about, because this came up actually in a few of other panels where we would talk about the aging infrastructure, everything needs to be replaced, the changing dynamics of supplied gas on the pipeline's result, transmission for renewables, oil pipelines. From your guy's perspective, when was the last time we had this sort of push on infrastructure and CapEx in the industry? I mean it's a big change from what it was five, six, seven years ago. But if you had to go back in time, where would you peg this sort of event to previous historical events?

MARK RUELLE: I think, you want to go around this away?

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Sure.

MARK RUELLE: I'll tell you the difference I've seen now, and I've been in the business about 30 years, what I've seen different now is used to grow to be able to meet the load. Today, we're growing to meet mandates. In other words, environmental mandates, whether it's renewable energy optimization, emission controls, the transmission requirements we talked about. Many of the requirements we have today are driven by standards that we need to meet. Aging infrastructure, I guess that's up to us whether we try to do it or not, but many of the utilities have standards for performance that the commission sets to ensure good reliability for customers.

So that's the difference I see today and going forward with things that we must do. I think the environmental controls that we talked about earlier are a good example of it, that you need to meet it, it's a pass through cost. We need to move forward with it. So I think those are really the drivers now that I hadn't seen in years part.

ROBERT HOGLUND: I would say for context, if you think about the electrification in the United States, it's easy for us young people to say, oh it's always been here, but Con Ed, the city utility in the 1960s and early 1970s, unit volume growth was 7% per year. We were putting in half a dozen substations per year. We had a boom in the last five years. The peak year we put three in. So there's been dramatically higher spending relative to the base in the past. Now, those of us that are young may not remember that. We were probably walking around in diapers or trying to get through kindergarten, but that doesn't mean that it didn't happen.

I think what's different this time around, and it's also a little tougher to grasp, is because a lot of our business has grew dramatically post World War II when electrification was big in large parts of this company. That means that we have a lot of facilities that are 60 years old and we have engineers that are really good at milking equipment for a long period of time, running it to fail, fixing it, and running it to fail again. A lot of these assets now are to the point where they failed enough. They're not really used and useful anymore, and that's what driving the spend in the big city distribution system.

JAMES SCILACCI: A comparison I guess would be when we went and built all our nuclear plants back in the late '70s and early '80s, there was dramatic growth across the nation. And I think it's a little different from then, because if you remember back then in some of the states, we had AFUDC earnings, non-cash earning. And so we were issuing stock to pay the dividend, and from a financial perspective that, I don't think, was as healthy. And today most of what we're building doesn't have AFUDC, large AFUDC components. So you have real cash earnings versus non-cash. So I think it's fundamentally different. It's higher today on a relative basis, very high when we did the nukes. But it is proportionally higher given for inflation than it was then.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: We're going to go ahead and open this up to one question from the audience in the interest of time. Any questions here for managing regulatory risk during a recession?

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: (Inaudible question - microphone inaccessible)

JOHN RUSSELL: I'll be glad to start. What we did in Michigan is we passed energy legislation a few years ago and for a real big ticket item, new nuclear plant, new coal plant, not environmental. But what we were able to do at that point is we will go through a process that will ensure that what we're building, the cost of what it costs to build, the amount of capital we need to spend is prudent. And that will continue as being prudent through any regulatory body, and that's the assurance that we need to move forward with those investments.

As was mentioned earlier in the growth base, you didn't have to worry about it because the growth was there to cover it. But when the growth wasn't there or there was cost overruns, that's what's caused the prudence issue.

What we're doing in Michigan is moving forward to get the agreement ahead of time before we make those large capital investments. Most of the other investments we make are done on an incremental basis. So those will risk the prudency as long as we align and communicate with the regulators beforehand.

ROBERT HOGLUND: As you probably remember, Vic, I started with the thesis, when I started in this job, I started with the thesis that T&D was lower risk than a generation into the business because we don't have big, chunky projects that can easily overrun and therefore are high priority partners for regulators. And part of my education has been, a good regulator can find a way to go after almost anything.

So we currently have capital review for 2005 to 2008 underway for the New York Public Service Commission where they assert that because we spent $1.6 billion over that three year period more than what they allowed in rates, that we may potentially have a prudence issue. And they're very keen to forget the evidentiary record in the case in which we asked for $1.1 billion more than they granted, and we think we have a pretty good justification why the incremental $500 million reflects largely commodity cost increases.

So I think it's a tricky issue. Having said that, I think a lot of the spend now is on either mandates like environmental, where I think the relationship between the regulator and the regulated is a little different, or it's on the distribution end of the business where the items are smaller, and I think the prudence risk per force is necessarily smaller as well. So there's I think a better dynamic this time around, but I would not tend to believe that prudence isn't an issue.

MARK RUELLE: I'll take a stab at this, Vic. One, as John indicated, we too in Kansas have a statutory predetermination standard. So it means you get agreement before you go out and spend a bunch of dough, and that helps, and I think that helps everybody. It helps regulators, it helps politicians, and it certainly helps investors and management. But even aside from that, as I indicated earlier, the concept of flexibility in an uncertain environment, I mean it's a religion to us. Because many of us are old enough to remember the last round of base load construction in a big way where there were prudency issues.

One of my colleagues is fond of saying, and I think he's right, when you decide to build a base load plant, you're going to be right and wrong in that decision five times before the plant goes commercial. And if the lumps of capital are so big and you're put in a situation where it's a she loves me, she loves me not game, and you got to hope that she loves you, well the day the plant goes commercial you put your regulators, you put your investors in a pretty tough situation.

So what we decided about three years ago is to really work the value of the flexibility in our wholesale contract portfolio, take advantage of our geography with renewables, take advantage of the fact that we have a very small natural gas exposure relative to the rest of the industry, and that we've got an environment where socially, politically, environmentally, people want transmission. And we have a policy environment where we can sight transmission in 120 days. And we've put together a portfolio of supply resource --

urn:contentItem:5X2P-9781-DYG2-R0PF-00000-00CNBC Anchor, Wall Street Analyst Discuss Future of Tech Sector on Technology Policy Institute Podcast 'Two Think Minimum'2019-09-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:00ZLexisNexisCNBC Anchor, Wall Street Analyst Discuss Future of Tech Sector on Technology Policy Institute Podcast 'Two Think Minimum'Targeted News ServiceWASHINGTON

Technology Policy Institute issued the following news release, dated Sept. 13:

CNBC Worldwide Exchange anchor and senior national correspondent, Brian Sullivan, discusses a variety of technology business and policy issues as a featured guest on a recent edition of the Technology Policy Institute's Two Think Minimum podcast.

Sullivan is joined by Laura Martin, managing director of Needham & Company and a TPI board member, and TPI President and Senior Fellow Scott Wallsten, who moderates the discussion. Topics include technology companies, e-sports, data privacy, competition and other technology sector and policy developments.

The podcast was recorded on the sidelines of TPI's annual Aspen Forum on August 20. Wallsten began the podcast by asking what each guest thinks about national policymakers' handling of technology issues in Washington.

"I think [policymakers] are late," said Laura Martin, citing competition between platform aggregators, as they get into each other's businesses and many seek to enter video. "The government is saying they are monopolies well that may have been true two years ago.

"The FAANGs [Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix and Google] are the past," Martin said. "They got big and now they are being looked at. But the thing that is going to get big based on consumer time will get ignored until it gets really big and hurtful [and] people are writing letters."

Like Martin, Sullivan says the marketplace is changing very quickly. "The 18-year-old in America isn't googling, he's playing Fortnite" while ordering pizza through Siri, he said.

Martin predicts significant market shifts, including likely tech company failures, because, among other reasons, "eSports and the rise of video game dominance in five years is going to have taken over consumers' time."

Concerning federal and state collaboration on potential government investigations of technology companies-a breaking news story Brian Sullivan advanced that morning during his on-stage, Aspen Forum interview of DOJ antitrust czar Makan Delrahim-Sullivan said, "Antitrust takes so long that by the time [a case is] over, [the decision] is almost irrelevant."

You can listen to the episode and others on TPI's blog. If you liked that one, find other Two Think Minimum episodes on Soundcloud, Blubrry, Spotify, Google Play Music, and iTunes.

urn:contentItem:5XXH-RN61-JCMN-Y25P-00000-00CNBC just confused VC Geoff Yang and presidential candidate Andrew Yang2020-01-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:00ZLexisNexisCNBC just confused VC Geoff Yang and presidential candidate Andrew YangMary Meisenzahl

Jan 06, 2020( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Justin Sullivan/Getty Images CNBC[1] accidentally posted an image about the 2020 election with several mistakes. It replaced a photo of democratic presidential candidate Andrew Yang[2] with VC Geoff Yang. The network, which soon apologized for the mistake, also used a photo of Kirsten Gillibrand[3] in place of Tulsi Gabbard[4]. Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories[5]. Being part of the "Yang Gang" took on a new meaning for the cofounder of Silicon Valley venture capital firm Redpoint Ventures on Monday.

Geoff Yang, the partner who founded the Menlo Park, Calif.VC firm two decades ago, surprised many of his peers on Monday when his face appeared in a chart on TV news network CNBC alongside Joe Biden, Bernie Sanders and the other candidates for the 2020 US presidential elections. While CNBC noted that Yang had raised $16.5 million in the fourth quarter for his campaign, the network had the wrong face, mistakenly identifying the VC investor for Andrew Yang, who also has a tech background and is running under the slogan to "Make America Think Harder."[6] Predictably, the snafu caused widespread mirth on Twitter. Yang's Press Secretary Erick Sanchez tweeted out the screengrab, saying "I see Andrew Yang every day, and I can't remember him ever looking like this."Tweet Embed: //twitter.com/mims/statuses/1214202682854060032?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw I see Andrew Yang every day, and I can't remember him ever looking like this. pic.twitter.com/bQF4ZHXY1l[7]Geoff Yang, who sits on AT...]'s board, also reacted on Twitter[9]. He wrote "Ummm. This is @geoff_yang[10] and I am NOT running for President." CNBC also mixed up candidate Tulsi Gabbard, replacing her photo with former candidate Kirsten Gillibrand. The network soon apologized[11] for the mistake. In an email to Business Insider, Geoff Yang declined to comment on who he is supporting in the 2020 race. "No comments, but I have gotten hundreds of emails and texts some offering donations! Funny, but makes it hard to get any work done," he said. Andrew Yang first gained attention for his $1,000 per month universal basic income[12] proposal. Some supporters initially saw his campaign as a meme or a joke[13], but he's outlasted several more establishment candidates, including Kamala Harris and Kirsten Gillibrand. urn:contentItem:5R9V-MVM1-JDJN-6502-00000-00CNBC launches Wholesome Returns, a convention specializing in well being care innovation2018-01-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:00ZLexisNexisCNBC launches Wholesome Returns, a convention specializing in well being care innovation

CNBC is excited to announce that we are launching a new conference called Healthy Returns: Investing in Health Care Innovation. This groundbreaking event will take place on March 28, 2018, in New York City in an effort that includes a world-class advisory board to help guide our editorial efforts. The will be coupled with TV and digital content before, during and after the conference.

Why Healthy Returns? Health care spending in the United States accounts for about 18 percent of our GDP, reaching $3.2 trillion in 2015, or $9,990 for every man, woman and child. There has certainly been no shortage of news coverage about the debate in Washington over the ACA/Obamacare, but Healthy Returns is not solely focused on policy or politics. Rather, we will be applying our distinctive CNBC lens to the business of health care, focusing on the most exciting innovations and investment opportunities.

Biotech, pharmaceutical and insurance companies, and those who invest in them, face unique challenges. From an uncertain regulatory environment to the exigencies of clinical trials, this is an industry rife with risk. But along with that risk, of course, is the possibility for big rewards, both clinically and financially. We are witnessing an extraordinary moment as precision medicine, gene editing and new approaches to immunotherapy, coupled with ever-increasing computing power, begin to lead to therapies that just a few years ago seemed totally out of reach.

Silicon Valley is now getting into the act, too, as , and circle. Big tech and well-funded start-ups are seeking to revolutionize everything from how we monitor and measure our health (wearables) to how we deliver treatment (surgical robots and smart pills). Whats clear is that health care is going through a period of rapid and significant medical and technological transformation.

The Healthy Returns advisory board will help guide our efforts in covering this transformation. Among those on the board: entrepreneurs such as Anne Wojcicki, founder and CEO of 23andMe, the hot genetic testing and analysis service; philanthropists such as Sean Parker, founder of Napster and founding president of Facebook who is now chairman of the Parker Institute for Cancer Immunotherapy, and Gates Foundation CEO Susan Desmond-Hellmann; leading medical technologists such as Dr. Eric Topol, one of the countrys leading voices on the use of genomics to drive transformative research; and top investors and executives such as Fred Hassan, special limited partner at Warburg Pincus and former CEO of Schering-Plough. For a full list of advisory board members, visit our .

We hope you enjoy our Healthy Returns stories on TV and digital, and will join us at our big event in March! 2017 Global Data Point.

I know you have thoughts some of these big issues. I want to get right to. I want to get right to it before we get to the substance can we just get to what I regard as being the blather, any reflections on last night since. At one point, the President did invoke I've learned my lesson here and Boca name that I didn't think was correct.Senator Warren: So, you know, my reaction last night is Donald Trump demonstrated again why he should not be President of the United States of America.

And look, you didn't have to watch the whole thing. All you had to do was just see that little clip, when he was asked to denounce white racism. Right, white supremacy. And what did he say he told the proud boys to stand by. That should do it for every person in this country. That is not the America that we want to be the America we want to be is an America that lifts up all of us that creates opportunity for all of us. Donald Trump just made it clear that's not who he is. And just in case that didn't seal the deal. His closer. That sounded a lot like to me that he was encouraging his supporters to go out and engage in voter intimidation, to keep American citizens from voting and getting their votes counted. That one really should have done it. So, you know, in that sense, to me, really short debate, two clips right there where Donald Trump made it clear that he cannot be trusted. As the leader of our nation.Cramer: Okay, understood. And I think that there's an American way. And I think that we all deal with the American ways so now let me get to something that you are the expert on. I am struggling with your views, because your views actually are very similar to what I regard is Ronald Reagan's views, actually when it comes to the disparity of wealth between CEOs and workers but I need to know do you think that it's possible, like, Marc Benioff from Salesforce says that business can be the greatest force for social change.Senator Warren: I believe that we can make change. But let's be clear about this. We live in a democracy and the whole premise behind that is it's one person, one vote. And that's how we're going to create a set of rules that work for all of us right it's that simple. But notice I could hear you before I came on and what were you talking about you're talking about Donald Trump's taxes. Right. And you were doing this fine lawyerly conversation about. Did he evade or avoid right did he stay on this side of the line, or that side of the line, frankly, Jim, it's the wrong question. The question is, how did we end up with a tax system that lets Donald Trump claim to be earning millions and millions and millions and millions of dollars. And it's a baby. Here are the loopholes that Donald Trump and people just like Donald Trump can slice through. How did we end up in an America where the average nurse pays what 15, 18 $20,000 in taxes the average teacher pays that kind of money in taxes that workers across this nation, literally, they paid 10s of thousands of dollars in taxes. People have quite moderate incomes middle class America, but Donald Trump can pay $750 in taxes. The problem here is that the system itself is broken and you gotta ask why and you want to know why. The reason is because of the Donald Trump's of the world. The people who have used their money and used their influence to get Congress to keep rewriting those laws, you know it's not like a bunch of lawmakers woke up one day and said, Gosh, we can help up nurses and teachers and and and and people who stopped grocery store shelves, or we could help out real estate developers, I know, let's give everything to the real estate developers and take it all away from everyone else. That's what's wrong with the system. It is the capture of government by the rich and powerful to make themselves richer and more powerful.Cramer: Senator Warren you're there. Is there a way to actually break the stranglehold you're you are fabulous professor, and you understood the code. You know how hard the code is what happens if you took a regular approach and just said you know what the code is no good. And what we're going to do is have everybody pay the same tax on everything, real estate stock, it doesn't matter. It's simple we make the code, two pages, America becomes a richer wealthier and absolutely more distributed, a distributed country. And I think you and I would agree that that's the way that should be the American way.Senator Warren: I'm all for rewriting the tax code, are you kidding, I mean, let's go. But the point is, we've got to break the influence of rich folks who make their voices heard, not a little bit, not a medium sized amount, not even a huge amount. They make their voices heard in Washington louder than anything else, you know, what was the one legislative achievement of Donald Trump, and the republicans do remember the one thing they managed to get through Congress, a trillion dollar tax cut that went largely to millionaires and billionaires and giant corporations and remember all those promises they made about what it was going to do for the economy and so you remember what the one thing actually did that you can measure is that it drove down revenues for the government to be able to run everything else. And, and that's the thing. Jim about this. It's not just that Donald Trump doesn't pay taxes, it's somebody else has to pay to keep this country going. Somebody has to pay for the roads and bridges. Somebody has to pay for the military. Somebody has to pay to keep our country working and nurses pay a big share teachers pay a big share grocery store clerks pay a big share and Donald Trump, just pays a tiny little bit. And that's because why money,Cramer: Do you still believe strongly in your idea that there should be a levy on accumulated wealth and your two cents on the dollar 2% on the porch is about 50 million to half a percent about 1 billion is that a way to get at it.Senator Warren: Sure. It's one of the ways we can do. Come on, Jim, people have been paying wealth taxes across this country forever. They're just usually called property taxes. And all I'm saying is for the top one 10th of 1% this tiny little fraction at the top, to say you know what, when you pay your wealth tax, it's not all just real estate for you. Let's include the stock portfolios and the diamonds and the rimbrant and give us just two cents, three cents if you're a billionaire on the dollar. And that will produce enough money because ultimately it's who's gonna pay that would give us enough money to provide child care for every baby in this country age zero to five universal pre K, it would give us enough money to pump billions of dollars into K 12 enough money to cancel student loan debt enough money to put $50 billion into historically black colleges and universities and enough money to make four years at a public institution tuition free for every kid who wants to get an education, technical school two year college four year college in other words, what it means to sense and invest in a whole generation of young people, we could build such a future in this country.Cramer:  Well let me push back in a realistic way, but you're talking about a Jeff Bezos paying huge amount you're talking about a Steve Ballmer pay huge amount you're talking about very powerful people. Mark Zuckerberg paying huge amount. These are people who are going to fight you tooth and nail they have incredible resources, what do you do, do you just decide, you know what I am going to beat these guys. Senator Warren, they have unlimited firepower.Senator Warren:  Wow, did you hear what he just said, This is about power. And you've just said, Be realistic in this democracy in 2020 boy folks in Washington, need to listen to Jeff Bezos because he's rich and not listen to the school teacher or the nurse or the grocery store clerk, because after all, they're not. That is not how democracy is supposed to work. And I'll tell you this, when you know thatCramer:  you don't. I mean, you understand that. Look, I, I want the school teachers I want to go back to the senator wittings day when I was doing. He was my professor, where we want to do guaranteed income for all these people with no taxes i mean i think that these people would should even that was Nixon's plan I mean, he'll think about the people I'm talking about, you know, Nixon favored higher taxes for the rich and lower taxes for the poor, or for the working poor Reagan favored higher taxes for the rich and lower taxes for the working poor. What the hell happened in our country that two of the most, I mean you can't you're supposed to mention Nixon but you know both of those presidents favored a better redistribution that we have now, how'd that happen.Senator Warren:  Well partly Citizens United. It's corruption in Washington. It's the influence of money and understand it absolutely is it's about money for campaign contributions, but it is so much more. It is about the lobbyists, it's about the bought and paid for think tanks. It's about the experts who are taking money from the rich folks and from the industries. It's about these industry groups. It's about the fact that big businesses and billionaires have figured out, they're gonna make more return on their money by investing in twisting the rules in Washington to help them. And to help them keep more of their money, help them deregulate so that they can externalize their costs. They figured that out and they are just pushing them. The pedal to the metal on this. But I tell you Jim I'm not giving up.Cramer: I know you're not, I know you favorite breaking up tech little lightning round here, what do we do with alphabet, Google.Senator Warren: Got to break it got to break these guys up. And the reason for this understand on every one of them. The very best part of what we can make work in this economy is when you've got markets that are working. And that means you got to have competition. So these guys who engage in these anti-competitive practices, the guys who engage in monopolistic practices, the guys who crush or buy up their competitors and just keep getting bigger, understand this. It's not only what they're doing. It's what they're doing to the rest of the market. It means we'll lose the vibrancy in the market, it means we lose the creativity, you've got a great idea, but you're going to go up against Amazon, you've got a terrific notion but you're going to be up against Google Good luck to you. And that's the whole point. that's the role of government, it's to blow the whistle and say these guys when they get too big when they get too dominant in market. Nope, can't do that. Got to break them apart, and get more competition going Cramer: ok well how about the banks, I mean we're hearing, we'll get there isn't a day that goes by that we don't read about a giant fine, which of course is paid by the shareholders senator, we read about how they may not be able to find the limited pool of black talent at these banks I mean we're, which of course is wrong. I don't understand how the banks, stay this size when they obviously can't Avoid chicanery.
Senator Warren: No and what you are exactly right. Part of this lay, again, at the feet of the bank regulators who are far more interested in watching out for the banks and helping them make sure that they get plenty of profits. But part of this is laid truly at the feet of our willingness to let the giants call the shots in Washington. And that's true whether you're talking about banking or you're talking about tech, or you're talking about big AG. It's the power and the money of these giants who are here. Who are saying, 'no, no, no. We like business as usual. You know, every time someone talks about nothing ever happens in Washington, you know, except that giant tax cut that Trump got through, and they use words like gridlock. Understand, this isn't about gridlock. This is about the system works great for those giants. Because nobody's in there to say we're going to enforce the antitrust laws, or we're going to toughen the antitrust laws, or we're going to stitch up those tax loopholes. And that's what we got to do.Cramer: Okay, so let's think about this for a second. You ran for President. Everything you articulated was right there. I know a huge number of young people, I don't know as many older people I know a huge number of young people who swear by you. Why did you not win the nomination?Senator Warren: Well, I wish I knew the answer to that one, but I lost. But look, I'm not sorry I ran because the things I argued for are still out there. The problems we have are still every bit as big as they were. Indeed, with this COVID-19, it has even gotten bigger. Inequality in this country, I talked about it every day when I was out on the trail. But look what we see now. Communities of color hit disproportionately hard by COVID-19. Just peel back that layer just a little bit and what do people start to understand finally? This has to do with generations of systemic racism, and it has to do with a black white wealth gap, a health gap, an entrepreneurship opportunity gap, an education gap, a housing gap. Racism that has pervaded the system and kept us from being the America that we should be.Cramer: And Senator, you left one out, of which I agree with all those, but you left one out. Gender diversity, okay. How about this statistic that I got from I'm familiar with because I used to own it. We are number 17 in the world in the percentage of female board members. How pathetic is that given the fact that women run 40% of the household spend -- of their finances, but almost 100% of their buying. How did this number occur? Why is that number occuring?Senator Warren: So look, we know the data on this. And that is folks who've got power, don't give it up easy Jim. If you're part of the club, you keep that power close and that means we have a lot of white men who are holding on to the power they've got and they don't plan to share it. They don't plan to share it with women, they don't plan to share it with African Americans, they don't plan to share it with Native Americans, they don't plan to share it with Latinos. That's the way this works. But here's the thing, Jim, there's more votes Cramer: But here's what confuses me. I know you and you understand markets. The most highest-rated, meaning the highest PE multiple stock, in the food group is McCormick, which also has the greatest diversity in the boardroom of any company in the food group. Now, is that not cut and dried? That if you want to do well, you become diverse. So what are these people missing? I didn't call them clowns out of respect of last night's debate. Why is it that these people at these boards don't look at McCormick and say, 'hey you know what? They're the most diverse. Most women, most Latino, most African American and they are doing better than everyone else. Why can't people see that? You and I see it.Senator Warren: You know Jim, I'm just going to underline your point because I think you're so right on this. I think that the evidence showed coming out of the 2008 crash that companies that had more than one woman on their board, companies that had women in well placed positions in the U.S. and around the world, those companies did better. They did better in terms of not crashing so hard and making it out faster on the other side. It is the reminder that you don't pull together a diverse team out of some notion of trying to engage in charity for someone. You pull together a diverse team, because a diverse team is what will make you strong. It is what will make you profitable. It is what will make your country -- your company robust and make your country strong. So, you do it out of but that's not how these guys look at it. You know, sometimes it takes getting a little bit out of your comfort zone, running the risk of making a mistake. And a lot of folks don't want to do that. Not the guys who already had the power.Cramer: You have proposed something that is so brilliant. Small business equity fund. A fund to close the gap, create 100,000 new minority businesses, your price tag is only 7 billion. Senator Warren why isn't that done right now?Senator Warren: No kidding.Cramer: Let's get it done.Senator Warren: Let me just lay it down so I'm sure everybody's following on this. So, what the data show is a lot of people talk about that Black-owned businesses need access to be able to borrow more money. But when you look at the comparisons with Black-owned businesses and white-owned businesses, what you see is it is no. They need some seed money, they need some equity to get them started and to cushion them in the early parts of getting those businesses launched. And that equity usually comes from accumulated family wealth. And where does that come from? It comes from homeownership. So, watch what happens here, Jim. For decades, decades in America, African Americans were just largely cut out the opportunity to buy homes. It was redlining. And cut out of the federally insured mortgages. And that wasn't just an idea. It was literally the law of the United States into the mid-1960s. So, as white families were building up more wealth through their homes, and building up more intergenerational wealth that is you know if grandma and grandpa could stay in the home until they died, they pass it on to the grandchildren or when they sold it there be a little more for the next generation -- that becomes the spur to be able to start a successful small business. African Americans just got cut out of that. For $7 billion, we could close that gap and African Americans, people of color who have been cut out for generations, would have the same kind of opportunity not just to start a small business but to start it and help it succeed.Cramer: Who's fighting that, Senator Warren? Who is fighting something that I think, again, is the American way? Which is equal opportunity, it's in the Constitution. You know the Constitution better than anyone who ran for President because you were a tremendous professor of law. I don't get who could be against something that is deeply ingrained within the Constitution.Senator Warren: Mitch McConnell, Donald Trump, every single sitting Republican senator that enables Mitch McConnell and Donald Trump. And I'll tell you exactly how. Every proposal, like that, that I put on the table and others put on the table, cannot get a vote in a Republican controlled Senate. I can't even get it out there for a floor debate to talk about what it would mean, and to be able to bring in Republicans and Democrats to vote for it. Mitch McConnell refuses to bring an idea like that, a bill like that and so many others, to the floor for a vote, and it goes back to what we talked about earlier. Why? Because he is there to serve the interests of the richest and most powerful. And if you put $7 billion of taxpayer money into equalizing entrepreneurial opportunity for people of color and for whites that's $7 billion that's going to have to come out of maybe their taxes. And they don't want any part of it. And besides that, they don't want the competition. They like things the way they are.Cramer: I want to leave a constructive note. Once again, what companies do the best? Take a company like Constellation Brands. They own Modelo and they own Corona. What do they do? They set up a fund for Latinos who have good ideas for any beverage. There. Why do they do it? Do they do it just because they are kind? Well, they happen to be kind, but they do it because they make more money for shareholders. How do we in a constructive way you and me get this done? How do we tell the tale that if you are more diverse, if you help minorities, if you invest in the community, you are going to have a higher stock price? That is true, Senator Warren. How do we get it out?Senator Warren: So, I love it. You keep talking about it, but understand this, Jim. Our responsibility is to change our government so it isn't just working for the rich and the powerful. We want to build opportunity in this nation. Opportunity for everyone. Not opportunity that is different depending on the color of your skin, or your gender, or who you love. We want to build opportunity. That's what builds the best America. And the way we do that is we build opportunity by making these kinds of investments. By understanding how racism and sexism and anti-Muslim attitudes have kept people from having those chances. It is the job of our government to say we're all going to pitch in a little so every kid gets a chance to build a future in this nation.Cramer: Senator Warren, I want to thank you so much. I think a lot of what you talked about is called again, I use the term American way, because that's how we grew up. That's what we learned. Somehow it got a little off track, but I know that you have strong convictions and a lot of these ideas. I'm sure there's pushback from hedge fund managers, pushback from the people at these big tech companies, but I think these must be discussed and never forget If you want your stock price higher be diverse. Thank you so much, Senator Warren. Always great to talk to you.Senator Warren: Always great talking to you, Jim. Take care. For more information contact: Jennifer Dauble
CNBC
