urn:contentItem:5T5D-JSW1-JB20-G23M-00000-00CNN Standing By It's Controversial Story On Lanny Davis And Not Naming Their Source Which Plays Into Being Fake News; Trump Blasts Big Tech Company Especially Google For Political Censorship; Speculations On Mueller's Action Sends Media Into Frenzy; Political Comments Made By Speakers At Aretha Franklin's Funeral; New Poll Shows Majority Of Americans Oppose NFL Players Kneeling During National Anthem; Don Lemon Criticizes Kanye West; U.S. And Canadians Representatives Continue Trade Negotiations2018-08-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:00ZLexisNexisINGRAHAM ANGLE10:00 PM ESTDinesh D'Souza, Howard Kurtz, Alan Dershowitz, Kendall Coffey, Antjuan Seawright, Kevin Jackson, Roger Fisk, Sean DuffyNEWSDomestic083101cb.257CNN Standing By It's Controversial Story On Lanny Davis And Not Naming Their Source Which Plays Into Being Fake News; Trump Blasts Big Tech Company Especially Google For Political Censorship; Speculations On Mueller's Action Sends Media Into Frenzy; Political Comments Made By Speakers At Aretha Franklin's Funeral; New Poll Shows Majority Of Americans Oppose NFL Players Kneeling During National Anthem; Don Lemon Criticizes Kanye West; U.S. And Canadians Representatives Continue Trade NegotiationsLaura Ingraham, Marianne Rafferty, Mollie Hemingway, Raymond Arroyo

(JOINED IN PROGRESS)

JASON CHAFFETZ, FOX NEWS HOST: It's available for pre-order now, on the book stands September 18th. Have a look at the deep state. I appreciate it. Have a wonderful weekend. "THE INGRAHAM ANGLE" is up next.

LAURA INGRAHAM, FOX NEWS HOST: Good evening from Chicago. I'm Laura Ingraham and welcome to THE INGRAHAM ANGLE Special: Trump's Week of Battles.

President Trump is a fighter. There's no doubt about that, and it's a good thing because he's facing attacks on multiple fronts. In the next hour, we're going to tell you how the media are putting stories out, some of them blatant lies to undermine the president's agenda. Alan Dershowitz will be here to discuss Trump's latest fight with the Justice Department. You won't believe what we're learning about DOJ official Bruce Ohr.

Raymond Arroyo is here with his "Friday Folly" segment, where he's going to tell us of how the funeral of a music legend at times became a political rally.

Plus, we've got updates about NFL players kneeling during the anthem and President Trump's efforts to remake the NAFTA agreement, all coming up.

But first, our top story, CNN caught red-handed. As we've been telling you this week, CNN's blockbuster story last month about Michael Cohen was dead wrong. The network went wild with an anonymously sourced report that claim Cohen was prepared to tell Mueller's team that President Trump knew in advance about that infamous 2016 Trump Tower meeting between Donald Trump, Jr. and a Russian lawyer.

We now know that CNN lied about Cohen's attorney, Lanny Davis being a source for the piece. And here's the kicker. Davis now says the story is false. But still CNN is sticking with its story. And "Business Insider" is reporting that the network isn't planning on revealing its alleged second source. Huh?

And the left wonders why Trump's fake news narrative is working. Joining me now for reaction is "The Federalist" Mollie Hemingway who's also a Fox News contributor, Howie Kurtz, host of Fox News' "Media Buzz" which airs at 11:00 a.m. on Sunday, and Dinesh D'Souza, a filmmaker whose new film "Death of a Nation" is in theaters now and will be in a special showing all weekend long over Labor Day.

Dinesh, let's start with you here. This is wild. I mean, CNN is you know, "This is CNN," the James Earl Jones booming voice. At one time back in the `80s when CNN started, it was considered kind of a gold standard of this new2 type of journalism. Where does it stand now after this Lanny Davis story, the complete bungle by the network?

DINES D'SOUZA, FILMMAKER; Well, one can almost think back nostalgically to the `80s when CNN would have shows like "Crossfire" where they would have a liberal, a conservative, Matt Buchanan on one side, Michael Kinsley on the other. That's not the CNN of today. Now, it's one thing to spin the news and interpret it in a manner that is consistent with your own ideological agenda.

It's a completely different thing to have a story I which you are reporting facts. The facts are exposed as false and you dig your heels in and say that they're true anyway. I mean, this is taking fake news to a new level and it is setting, you may say, almost a new standard of deception that I think will haunt CNN for a while.

INGRAHAM: Yes. Dinesh, your movie, "Death of a Nation." This is like death of journalism. Howie Kurtz, I know that cables compete with each other and it can be pretty rough and tumble and one side -- I get that. But this is unbelievable.

They claimed that they tried to, what, contact Lanny Davis initially with the story and that he declined to comment but it turns out he was initially the source of the story. I mean, this story gets worse and worse the more people marinate on it.

HOWARD KURTZ, FOX NEWS MEDIA BUZZ SHOW HOST: Yes, but Lanny Davis has told me that he never confirmed this allegation for CNN and then he sort of outed himself as a source. Look, CNN is trying to defend the indefensible.

It will not discuss on the air, will not discuss publicly what went wrong with the story about what Michael Cohen knew that Michael Cohen's lawyer now says it's not true. And this one sentence we standby our story isn't working because the network is accusing the president of lying about his knowledge about that Trump Tower meeting.

I'll tell you one other thing, Laura. If the White House had done something like this, throw out an incendiary charge and then stand by as the story begun to crumble, CNN and lots of other news organizations would be hammering the place for stone walling.

INGRAHAM: Mollie, and it's not just how they're stone walling tonight, it's how damaging the particular allegation was that they ran with, apparently with some source they said was Lanny Davis, which ended up kind of not being Lanny Davis. So it's the underlying allegation about that Trump Tower meeting which we know would have been at the crux of the Mueller investigation.

MOLLIE HEMINGWAY, FOX NES CONTRIBUTOR: Well, they claimed it was a bombshell when they first reported the story. And as the story is falling apart, I think part of the reason why they're unable to take responsibility for flubbing the story is that they hyped it so much. But it's really part of a pattern of behavior for CNN as it relates to the Russia conclusion conspiracy theory that they have been pushing for a year and a half.

And there had been other stories that they claim to have multiple anonymous sources that also fell through. You remember that they claim that Don, Jr. had advance knowledge of a WikiLeaks dump while they claim they have multiple sources, it turned out not to be true and they never explained how their multiple sources got it wrong.

They also claimed that James Comey would contradict Donald Trump's testimony about how James Comey had told him three times he wasn't under investigation. But we all saw that testimony. He admitted that he had told President Trump that three times, just as President Trump said. They never explained how they got that wrong. And these are just three examples of many stories that they have gotten wrong about the Russia collusion theory.

INGRAHAM: Now Dinesh, CNN is not the only network under fire for botching a huge story getting it wrong. But according to now new reports, the top brass at NBC tried to put the kibosh on Ronan Farrow's bombshell -- real bombshell story about Harvey Weinstein's sexual predation, basically forcing Ronan Farrow to take the story to "The New Yorker" magazine where everybody knows by now he ultimately won a Pulitzer Prize.

And tonight the rumors are also swirling that NBC News chairman, Andy Lack, is on the hot seat. And this is after President Trump weighed in on NBC's troubles last night.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Remember the lines from NBC which is probably worse than CNN. But the word is they're firing the head of NBC. What a great thing to do. How smart.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: Dinesh, this is unreal. Harvey Weinstein has a lot of power.

D'SOUZA: I think if the CNN story was a lie of commission, the NBC story is a lie of omission. Now, just think about how powerful their ideology would have to be because, remember, this is actually not a lie that would have helped Trump. This actually is a lie to cover up a principle, the principle of sexual harassment, the principle of sexual abuse, which is actually a principle on the left.

And so essentially this principle could only be trumped by a greater principle on the left. And the greater principle on the left here is we have to protect our own team. There are very powerful people on the left, George Soros, Harvey Weinstein, and it is an unwritten rule in a sense of progressive journalism that these people are untouchable and that you have to run defense for them and run protection for them. I believe that was what was going on at NBC.

INGRAHAM: Yeah, he thought he was untouchable and Harvey Weinstein thought everyone else was touchable, that's the problem here. Howie Kurtz, this is another wild story. Harvey Weinstein had enormous amount of influence in Hollywood, enormous amount of political clout with all the fundraisers he hosted, the money he raised, and deep friendships within the peacock.

I mean, he and Andy Lack I hear were very good friends. What happened to the "we treat all women the same as men. We believe in women's rights"? And when this Ronan Farrow, a young journalist was hot on the trail of this story, general counsel was saying, "you better back off or we're going to smear you." Again, these are reported allegations by I guess the producers of Farrow's work.

KURTZ: Right. Well, that particular allegation is denied by NBC and I don't know how much pressure Weinstein brought to (inaudible) but it remains a huge embarrassment for NBC that after eight months of (inaudible) let Ronan Farrow walk out the door with that prize-winning story that essentially launched the MeToo Movement.

And now you have Farrows investigative reporter -- producer, excuse me -- who just left NBC saying this is a massive breach of journalistic integrity by NBC, but NBC was never enthusiastic about the story. NBC claims he didn't have enough and then (inaudible) willing to do on camera, but two months later, this meticulously reported piece appears in "The New Yorker" and it looked like NBC just didn't have the guts to take on Harvey Weinstein.

INGRAHAM: But what's your gut on this, Howie? Do you think this producer is blowing smoke here? I mean, it sounds a little odd to me, doesn't it? Like, oh, we didn't have enough -- they said today he didn't have enough sources. It wasn't well sourced enoghh. I think he was working on it and they came down on him and said --

KURTZ: Oh yes. When you're a reporter, you know whether your bosses are enthusiastic particularly about a sensitive investigative piece. NBC was not. NBC was willing to let him walk out the door and so nothing can change the fact that NBC blew this one big time.

INGRAHAM: And Mollie, before we let you go, this story also bled into Andrew Cuomo because the report came out that he pulled back on an investigation into Weinstein I guess after what Weinstein's attorney gave a $25,000 donation. So, it even bleeds into that part of the political world.

HEMINGWAY: It's really clear that we see a lot of stories that get suppressed or elevated depending on political affiliations or friendships and that's really inappropriate. We want to believe that our legal institutions and our media institutions will tell the story regardless of where it takes them or apply justice regardless and that is a problem that we're facing in this country right now with different standards for different people.

INGRAHAM: All right. We have one more topic. We have time for that one final topic. President Trump last night also shared his thoughts on the current censorship controversy with big tech.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Look at social media. It's a thing called free speech rights. You look at Google, Facebook, Twitter, and other social media giants, and I've made it clear that we as a country cannot tolerate political censorship, blacklisting, and rigged search results. And you know it can go the other way also. We will not let large corporations silence conservative voices.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: Well, the focus on this from President Trump and conservatives may be having an effect. With reports like this one from the "New York Times" stating that some Facebook employees are fighting against this intolerant liberal culture.

Dinesh, you have written about this in books and spoken about this on college campuses. The west coast, otherwise effectually (ph) known as the left coast, especially in big tech, overwhelmingly left wing, overwhelmingly probably voted for Hillary. And yet they say, oh, this is just an algorithm. You're all floating conspiracy theories, but now you got Facebook employees complaining about the mono-culture.

D'SOUZA: This I think is very scary. So many conservatives fled to social media to escape the bias of the mainstream media. And now to discover this effort to sort of take people and make them into digital non-persons, I mean, one has to go back to all this (inaudible) George Orwell to find out this kind of stuff going on now.

A lot of people say, well, gee, these are private companies. They should be able to do whatever they want. But this is actually not true. If Google or Facebook decided for example we're going to shadow ban blacks or we're going to shadow ban Latinos. These companies would be shut down overnight.

They know that they can't do that and they wouldn't even dare, but apparently with conservatives they feel like it's OK to have political discrimination even though I don't see fundamentally the difference here between political discrimination and discrimination on any other basis.

INGRAHAM: Howie, how big of an issue is this? I mean, I can tell when my radio audience, it blows up the lines. Everyone wants to talk about it. Everyone seems to have an experience with it. I know it seems anecdotal but I find Bing by the way -- Bing is the best search engine -- the least biased in Bing. For whatever reason, that's what I've discovered. Howie?

INGRAHAM: Right. Well, it's a huge issue because social media is the new public square. And Facebook and Twitter both have acknowledged that they have a problem with instances of bias against conservatives. I think the evidence against Google is a little less clear.

So President Trump and others on the right are obviously going to speak out about this because if you don't, you know, you can disappear if you don't show up in the search rankings or in0 the trending topics or whatever. But at the same time, I don't think government regulation is the answer. So there has to be another way.

INGRAHAM: Yes. Mollie, we talked about this earlier. There's a thought that given the enormity of these corporations, and as Howie said and Dinesh pointed out, this is a public square today. This is the equivalent of what, you know, we used to see in the old town square with people with a bull horn.

And so could there be a movement to treat them more like public utilities, so they have some quasi, you know, government oversight of these entities or would that open up a total can of worms perhaps in the other direction at some point?

HEMINGWAY: I personally am not a fan of regulation as an answer to this situation, but these companies absolutely have sometimes huge market share, the percentage of which would make standard oil blush. They are cognizant that they are going to make the government want to weigh in.

Just because though they're not governmental entities does not mean they aren't threats to free expression. In the same way that people get mad when President Trump criticizes the media because they claim that that's a threat to free expression. It's also a threat when big tech is telling people what they can and can't say.

INGRAHAM: All right guys. Thank you so much. And wild speculation becomes a media manufactured frenzy over the Mueller investigation. Details on the latest desperate play with Alan Dershowitz, next.

INGRAHAM: If you've been watching other news anchors and pundits over the last day, you may think they sound like a bunch of kids on Christmas Eve. Now, why am I saying that?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIPS)

ANA CABRERA, CNN HOST: You made it to Friday. It is the beginning of the Labor Day weekend and talk heating up that special counsel Robert Mueller could drop an August surprise.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Axios looking at speculation over whether Bob Mueller may actually make some sort of an announcement today.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It's hot speculation among the president's lawyers that today might be a day of action for Robert Mueller.

(END VIDEO CLIPS)

INGRAHAM: Well, today's not quite over yet, but it's a nice serving of wild unsourced speculation on a Friday. Come on, guys, the news isn't that boring today. There's a lot happening. But are the president's critics grasping at any straws over the Mueller probe at this point?

Joining us now to analyze is Alan Dershowitz, author of the big bestseller "The Case Against Impeaching Trump." We're also joined by Kendall Coffey, a former U.S. attorney. Great to see both of you. Professor Dershowitz, that is quite amusing.

I've been hearing, it's coming, it's coming, there's something coming. I don't think Mueller's office is leaking anything. They've been pretty tight. So, is this just, you know, a case of desperate wishful thinking on the part of the media?

ALAN DERSHOWITZ, PROFESSOR EMERITUS, HARVARD LAW: I think they thought that we're now two months away from the beginning really of the election. And Justice Department regulations say you shouldn't have matters that might interfere with voting or interfere with the election or put a thumb on the scale of voting within two months. So, this was a time when maybe something would have happened.

But look, I think today what's happened is news reporting has become part of the adversary system. Kendall and I are used to the adversary system. He's one of the world's great lawyers. He was my lawyer, in fact. And he and I both understand the adversary system.

One side presents its view of the facts, the other side presents its view of the facts, then you have a judge or a jury decides. That's what's happening with journalism today. And wishful thinking substitutes often for capital analysis.

INGRAHAM: And, Kendall, we're going to play -- we have a couple of different George Stephanopoulos sound bites. We'll play the second one where again -- this guy has been around for a while now. He used to work for the Clinton's obviously, but he's been around for a while, but this is what constitutes reporting today. Let's watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS, ABC NEWS HOST: The New York Attorney General has filed suite against the Trump Foundation which could lead to a criminal referral. The Manhattan District Attorney also considering charges against the Trump organization. Trump facing lawsuits in Maryland and D.C. over the constitution of (inaudible) clause.

And of course special counsel Robert Mueller investigating possible collusion with Russia and obstruction of justice. The bog question going forward, will any of these investigations lay the groundwork for impeachment proceedings in Congress?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: Nothing's changed. Nothing's changed. And we're reporting it breathlessly like this is all new stuff. Kendall

KENDALL COFFEY, FORMER U.S. ATTORNEY: Yes, I mean, I've never seen a speculation become so intoxicating to the media. I have to say by the way as in aside. Alan Dershowitz is the greatest legal talent in America and a personal hero of mine.

INGRAHAM: Oh, you guys are too much. You guys are too much.

COFFEY: Alan is -- Alan speaks for himself. He is magnificent. But let me talk about the election because they're not supposed to drop bombshells on the midterm. Who knows if there's any bombshells to drop? And let's also recognize that the election is coming up very fast. If there's a two-month standard years ago, early voting in Florida, pretty important state, starts around October 27th.

Overseas absentees go out next month and by October, beginning of October, domestic absentees go out. So, I don't think there is any bombshell that they are rolling out anytime soon, but from the standpoint of avoiding interference with an election, I think the deadline has passed.

INGRAHAM: All right. Professor Dershowitz, the guy who's already in the middle of the Lanny Davis-Trump Tower story anonymous source controversy, Jim Sciutto, who a name I always mispronounce. He also weighed in on the speculation. Let's watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JIM SCIUTTO, CNN HOIST: You used the term constitutional crisis and that phrase has been uttered a number of times and warned about on a number of things. In this environment, though, would it really be received that way, right? Because arguably the president has shirked constitutional responsibility, certainly broken norms a number of times, frankly without consequence.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: Broken norms. Now we're at broken norms, Alan.

DERSHOWITZ: Well, I just don't agree with that. Well, you know, the system of checks and balances is working very, very effectively. The courts are striking down some executive orders, upholding some. The media is critical of the president, some supporting the president. The academy is generally putting pressure against the president. Churches, business, everybody is involved in checking and balancing everybody else.

Democracy is working. This is not a constitutional crisis. If the president is subpoenaed, he'll go to court. And if he goes to court he may win, he may lose. And if he loses he will comply with the orders of the court. This is the way Madison had in mind when he created our awkward system of checks and balances, which was not designed to promote efficiency, but to avoid tyranny. It's working.

INGRAHAM: Kendall, I'd say I'm not sure Madison had a special counsel in mind. I might beg to differ with the professor there. I don't know about that. To me it seems like this has gone way beyond a check and a balance. Check and balance was impeachment and conviction of a sentence. I'm not sure a special counsel is what any of our framers intended.

But I want to run another topic because I have you two gentlemen here. I would like to get your thought on another Mueller-related tip. Two sources told Fox News' Catherine Herridge, that DOJ's Bruce Ohr kept a Mueller deputy in the loop about anti-Trump Steele dossier. So, in other word, does that endanger Mueller's ethical standing? I'll go to kendall on that.

COFFEY: Well, it's troubling, isn't it? I mean, if you think about -- and whether it splashes over to Bob Mueller is a different question. But it's obvious that Bruce Ohr's wife was working for a private company funded by Democrats. Some of my best friends are Democrats (inaudible), but nevertheless, that is a glaring conflict of interest.

And what interactions he had with others, which were frankly outside of his immediate duties as the director of OCDETF, which focuses on drug trafficking organizations, its also in (inaudible). So it raises a lot of questions. DOJ in my mind has not done a satisfactory job of explaining it. They're really effective at investigating others, but when they go under the microscope, sometimes we don't get a lot of clarity.

INGRAHAM: All right, Alan, at the end of the week here, any more thoughts on Bruce Ohr as a close door testimony this week when his name has been occupying a lot of air time, for obvious reasons with his connection with Christopher Steele. His wife of course works at Fusion GPS. You know the drill.

DERSHOWITZ: Well, I was prepared to give Bruce Ohr the presumption of innocence. He was a student at Harvard Law School. Everybody tells me he's a really good guy. And the thing that really put me away from Ohr, maybe overcame the pure presumption of innocence, is the presence of his wife at a lunch or breakfast or whatever it was, meeting where obviously he was trying to obtain information in an official capacity and his wife was working for a private company.

I do think that the inspector general now has to really look into that relationship. And I trust the inspector general. I think he's one of the very few people who come away from all of this looking very good. And I would leave it to the inspector general to give us a thorough investigation or good answer as to the relationship between Bruce Ohr, his wife, the company, the Democrats, the Justice Department. It's very complicated.

INGRAHAM: All right, gentlemen, thank you so much. And a musical legend's funeral turning political? And Ryan Gosling setting up a huge controversy around the American flag and his new Neil Armstrong biopic. All that in "Friday Follies" with Raymond Arroyo.

MARIANNE RAFFERTY, FOX NEWS HOST: We're live from America's News Headquarters, I'm Marianne Rafferty. John McCain receiving the highest honor from Congress today, lying in state in the capitol rotunda. The Arizona senator is just the 30th person in the nation's history to receive this honor joining a distinguished list that includes President Abraham Lincoln, John F. Kennedy, and Ronald Reagan. Members of Congress gave tribute during today's ceremony after which members of the public were also allowed to pay their respects.

President Trump pushing for a new deal with Canada, but negotiations with Canada are off to a rocky start. The Toronto star today saying it was given off the record remarks from President Trump where he said he refused to compromise with Canada. President Trump called the leak a serious violation, but added that at least Canada knows where it stands.

I'm Marianne Rafferty. Now back to the INGRAHAM ANGLE.

INGRAHAM: It's Friday, and you know what that means.

Ryan Gosling's new Neil Armstrong biopic has set off a huge controversy and a boycott is under way. For more on that and the political edge of Aretha Franklin's funeral, we're joined by "New York Times" bestselling author of the "Will Wilder" series, and FOX News contributor, Raymond Arroyo. Now, Ryan Gosling, Raymond, he's such an affable, nice guy. It sounds like such an interesting biopic, astronaut. Why could this be possibly in any way cantankerous or controversial?

RAYMOND ARROYO, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Laura, they decided not to show Neil Armstrong planting the American flag on the moon, which is of course a fact of his life. Now, their reasoning for doing this, Gosling says in an interview around the Venice film festival, is this, and we'll put it up on the screen. He says, "I think this was widely regarded in the end as a human achievement, and that's how we chose to view it. So I don't think that Neil viewed himself as an American hero. From my interviews with his family and people that knew him, it was quite the opposite. And we wanted the film to reflect Neil."

Now, I don't understand how planting a flag on the moon in any way contradicts his being a humble hero or being reluctant to embrace that moniker as the hero.

INGRAHAM: It's another way of trashing patriotism. It's another way of moving beyond the nationalism or nationalistic spirit, fervor of the moment. And Chuck Yeager tweeted out, Raymond, who obviously knew Neil Armstrong well, he basically threw some water on what Gosling said, that he wouldn't like that flag, he mentioned, he didn't consider it an American achievement. It's ridiculous.

ARROYO: My feeling is, if you're doing a biopic, stick to the facts. He planted an American flag. Plant an American flag. Now there's a boycott movement, a #boycottfirstmanmovement. And this thing is sparking all sorts of outrage, and it's not even out yet.

INGRAHAM: Yes. What's that on his space outfit there? I think that's an American flag. Yes, Chuck Yeager said, not the Chuck I knew, basically, he's 95 years old, and he still had it in him. Yes, look at that flag on his astronaut uniform there. Come on.

All right, Raymond, what else is happening? We had kind of dueling funerals today. It was something on television. You had the John McCain funeral and then you had the -- or memorial service. He was lying in state at the capital. Then you Aretha Franklin funeral in Detroit.

ARROYO: Two great Americans, a musical legend, a statesman, both being honored. But both these events in some ways, particularly Aretha Franklin's funeral, turned very political. Here is Al Sharpton at the queen of soul's funeral in Detroit.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REV. AL SHARPTON: On Sunday on my show I misspelled "respect," and a a lot of you all corrected me.

(LAUGHTER)

SHARPTON: Now I want you all to help me correct President Trump to teach him what it means.

(APPLAUSE)

SHARPTON: When word had went out that Ms. Franklin had passed, Trump said she used to work for me. No, she used to perform for you. She worked for us.

(APPLAUSE)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ARROYO: I don't know why they have to politicize everything, but we see this across American life. People just want to turn sports, now even the great celebration of a life, a musical legend, the queen of soul, it's being twisted and turned into a political rally.

INGRAHAM: Raymond, no, no, this was so gratuitous. And, again, Aretha Franklin, one of the great American voices of all time. Didn't she get an award from George W. Bush? I guess she was a Democrat, but she didn't seem like an overtly political person. Maybe I missed that. Maybe I wasn't aware of that. But it just seemed completely out of step. And then you had Farrakhan up on stage. You had Jesse Jackson, but Farrakhan was an interesting person to have there on the same stage as Bill Clinton and other luminaries.

ARROYO: Ariana Grande took the stage, Chaka Khan. This was "The Voice" meets "Showtime at the Apollo." It was unbelievable. Everybody trying to top one another. And as you said, it was a rather interesting backdrop to Ariana Grande. And it looks like Farrakhan and Bill Clinton got quite an eyeful.

But here's my larger problem with this. Rather than focus on the individual whose life is being celebrated, it turns into everybody elbowing each other to get their moment on the stage. Even Maxine Waters managed to barge into this celebration. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Councilwoman -- I'm sorry, congresswoman who has been attacked like never before because she's a strong black woman. Congresswoman Maxine Waters from southside L.A., South Central.

(APPLAUSE)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Everybody just point over there. Tell her, we've got your back. Come on, say it so everybody will hear you out there. We've got your back.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ARROYO: But Maxine during the Wakanda salute there from "Black Panther." So everybody got their moment in the spotlight. You know, Laura, my problem with this is both of these funerals had become television events. Multi-venues, star-studded lineups, they really are made for TV events. And my concern is we're going to see people ahead of time booking the rights to their own funeral so that the networks can get -- Netflix announces Cher's funeral. They've got the exclusive right. I don't see how this serves the end of celebrating a life and bringing people together. We're using great lives to divide Americans, and that's not --

INGRAHAM: Some mean person on Facebook said something like, Aretha Franklin's memorial service was so great that it's been picked up for ten episodes on Netflix. I almost fell over. But, OK, I guess it was on for four or five hours. But, my goodness, it was star-studded and it did get political.

ARROYO: Six hours.

INGRAHAM: Six hours, that's all. OK. And Raymond, thanks so much.

And as the NFL season prepares to kick off, there's new data on just how many Americans side with President Trump over the National Anthem protest. Why it should send chills through the league, next.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I know you well. You love our country. You're proud of our history. And you always respect our great American flag.

We are standing up for the heroes who protect America. We are proudly standing up for our National Anthem.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAURA INGRAHAM, FOX NEWS HOST: Well, that was President Trump in Evansville, Indiana, last night. And when the NFL season is ready to kick off, the National Anthem protests are yet again taking center field, pun intended. The league has plenty of reason to be concerned. A new "Wall Street Journal"/NBC News poll finds that 54 percent of voters think that kneeling during the anthem is not appropriate. And that's compared to 43 percent who say it's a fair way to protest racial inequality.

Joining me now with their reactions, Kevin Jackson is an author and a FOX News contributor, and Antjuan Seawright is a Democratic strategist. Gentlemen, it's great to see you tonight. Antjuan, let's start with you. The numbers aren't hugely disparate there, a majority saying the National Anthem, kneeling is not appropriate. But there's a sizable number of people saying it's fine, it doesn't really bother them. It's not clear that this is probably good, ultimately, for NFL viewership, though, Antjuan. I'm ready to go to the Notre Dame game tomorrow night. And college football is where it's at. I'm sorry. NFL football, I just know a lot of people who are just not all that jazzed on it. And I think this is part of the reason. Even if it's not intended to be disrespectful to the military, a lot of military veterans do feel that way. And I think that ends up hurting the whole experience for just a lot of folks.

ANTJUAN SEAWRIGHT, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Well, Laura, a couple things. I think sometimes what gets lost in the conversation is why this even started. This started because Kaepernick felt like black and brown people were mistreated at the hands of law enforcement. That's number one.

Number two, when you look at polls, and I'll take this scenario or any other scenario where people are being surveyed, it's all about how the question is asked, who is doing the asking, and how the question is being framed. But if you look at the NFL and you look at the bottom line, their revenue numbers, their revenue increased by five percent last year, not to mention the $50 million Amazon deal for streaming that was signed.

And so while these people may say they may not agree with the protests, I tend to believe that they still will watch the NFL. And football, like any other sport, is one of the very few things that most people, Democrats, Republicans, black or white, rich or poor, agree on. I just hate it's turned into a political football, no pun intended.

INGRAHAM: Yes, well, Kevin, I don't think anyone is trying to make it political. I think people --

SEAWRIGHT: Well, the president is, Laura.

INGRAHAM: Well, I think the president is standing up for what he believes in, which is just like the folks who are kneeling. They're kneeling for what they believe in, and the president is standing up for what he believes in. You can't have it one way and say this whole side gets to do this when the president can't talk about what he believes. Kevin, your thoughts on this?

KEVIN JACKSON: As Jerry Glanville said one time, NFL is going to stand for "Not For Long." He can quote all the numbers and statics he wants. The NFL is in triage. And I don't know why they're on this self-defeating path, but they like being on it. And it reminds me of what the Democrats are doing in going against Donald Trump in many ways.

SEAWRIGHT: Here we go.

JACKSON: At the end of the day -- yes, here we go. You're exactly right. Here we go. When you look at what's going on with what Donald Trump is standing up, the flag, he's standing up for veterans. By the way, he's also standing up for police. I've got a film coming out called "Bleeding Blue," and one of police in there says, hey, when something happens in your neighborhood, are you going to call a cop or are you going to call Colin Kaepernick? And he's exactly right. The police are going to have to do their jobs, and Colin Kaepernick, whether he likes it or not, he started a trend. And, Laura, I don't know what the statistics are, but I'll tell you, the overwhelming number of Americans believe in the flag, believe in the Anthem, believe in standing for it, and believe in the military, and believe in the police.

SEAWRIGHT: You can take a knee in protest but also stand up for believing in America and everything she stands for.

JACKSON: Take a knee for the people killed in Chicago.

SEAWRIGHT: Again, I'll say, you can focus on why this even started, the fact that African-American, black and brown people are five times more likely to be mishandled or killed at the hands of law enforcement. This is why that started. And so while you can see these people are not pro- America, look, my father served in the military. My father served so that these players would have the right to take their knee.

JACKSON: More black people are killed by other black people than cops. And you can argue this as much as you want. Randy Moss wore a tie to get inducted into the NFL Hall of Fame and it had 12 black people's names on it that expanded over a decade. This idea that cops are out hunting and killing black people is ridiculous.

SEAWRIGHT: No one ever said they were out hunting and killing black people. I said they were mishandled at the hands of law enforcement. Statistics will prove that to be true.

INGRAHAM: We've got to move on. We've got other topics we want to hit while I have you both here. So I want to get your reaction to this. Last night CNN's Don Lemon took a pretty nasty shot at Kanye West over Kanye's support for President Trump. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR: It's like a word salad where you realize that Kanye West, entitled to his own opinion, but is not very bright and not very -- when it comes -- I'm talking about this position, not overall, but when it comes to these issues, he's not clued in. He needs to read about it before he speaks about it. I'm not saying he's not a bright person. I take that back. That's not what I meant. But when it comes to this particular issue, he needs to look at a book, read some history, and understand what he's talking about.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: That's pretty condescending coming from Don Lemon, who himself has had a few wobbly moments. Let's watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I love you, too, but we really don't need to see what's about to happen here. I love you, Don. No, keep it closed. OK, I'm cutting you off after this one. Should I cut him off?

DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR: A lot of people have been asking about that, about black holes and on and on and on, and all of these conspiracy theories. Let's look at this. Noah says, "What else can you think about? Black hole? Bermuda Triangle." And then Deji says "Just like the movie "Lost?" And of course it's also referencing "The Twilight Zone," which has a very similar plot. That's what people are saying. I know it's preposterous. But is it preposterous?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: He was talking in that last sound bite about the Malaysian jet that disappeared, crashed, but could have been pulled up by a black hole. I mean, I guess. I'm being charitable tonight. I guess.

JACKSON: You don't have to have Don Lemon being drunk to showcase his lunacy. Just watch his program any night.

SEAWRIGHT: Because you don't agree with him.

JACKSON: No. I don't agree with you, but you're sitting here and I'm not interrupting you. Look, at the end of the day, when you look at what he said about Kanye West, he's trying to correct a grown man who dare have an opinion that differs from his. And, oh, by the way, Donald Lemon, Kanye happens to be right. There are many reasons for us to be looking at Donald Trump through the prism, it certainly is black folks, to be looking to Donald Trump as a person who's done a lot more for blacks than Barack Obama.

SEAWRIGHT: Oh, Jesus Christ, man.

JACKSON: And people don't want to admit this. And for Don Lemon and this particular gentleman to keep talking about Donald Trump as if he's some bad guy, or Kanye West who is bringing out what we're calling the Kanye effect is ridiculous. More black people are waking up because of Kanye West and his comments, because they're tired of being demonized, because --

INGRAHAM: All right, let's go to Antjuan. Antjuan?

SEAWRIGHT: Laura, that sounds all good. What Don Lemon did -- he corrected his statement.

INGRAHAM: Antjuan, Antjuan.

JACKSON: I know, but I'm going to interrupt him like he did me, Laura.

SEAWRIGHT: What Don Lemon corrected was Kaney's position, and Kanye even apologized and walked it back, his comment about enslavement a couple of days ago on a national radio show because he was actually wrong. And I appreciate him taking his comments back.

JACKSON: He wasn't wrong.

SEAWRIGHT: Look, I am not for criticizing someone for having an opinion because we all have one.

JACKSON: Yes, you are.

INGRAHAM: Yes, why not?

SEAWRIGHT: Make sure when you speak of a certain instance, make sure that the facts are very, very clear. And I'm glad that Kanye West was able to be man enough to walk back his comments.

INGRAHAM: Guys, we've got to roll. All right, we've got to roll, guys. Thanks so much for joining us tonight.

I have a question, though. Is President Trump about to prove his naysayers wrong and score a huge victory for America? Well, how about in trade? Back in a moment.

INGRAHAM: Canada feeling the heat from President Trump over a new trade deal. Tensions spilled out in the public view throughout the day under a looming deadline. Take a listen to Canada's minister of foreign affairs.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHRYSTIA FREELAND, CANADIAN MINISTER OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS: We are committed to speaking for Canada to a deal which is a good deal for Canada, not just any deal. We are very good as Canadians at finding win-win compromises. At the end of the day, though, we are only going to sign a deal that's good for Canada.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: Now, a final agreement was not yet inked, reached today. But talks are set to resume next Wednesday. And my sources are telling me they're very close.

Joining us now to analyze is Wisconsin Republican Sean Duffy, along with Democratic strategist Roger Risk. Great to see you both. Roger, let's start with you. This issue of trade is something I've been writing about for, I don't know, about 20 years. And Bob Lighthizer, Jared Kushner, Luis Videgaray who was on our show exclusively on Monday night, and Freeland were all behind closed doors today. They're hammering this out. It's very complicated. The agricultural subsidies that Canada gives, especially to its dairy farmers, are incredibly important to Quebec. And that's a sticking point. But my sources are telling me they're extremely close. And no one wants Canada to walk away from the table. Canada doesn't and obviously the administration doesn't. Your reaction tonight?

ROGER FISK, FORMER OBAMA ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: I think it's almost the tale of two trade talks. I find some encouraging elements to how the administration has conducted itself with the Mexican set of the trade talks. That's been more sober, more process-driven. They've been working on it for a year. I hope that the success of that as we move forward starts to guide how the president views the resources around him, starts to maybe trust in some of the professionals that are there to help him.

The Canadian discussion is obviously much more accelerated and I think is going to take more time maybe than what we think right now. And then there's other factors that are going to make this more difficult as we go ahead. We have the 90-day window with Congress. If you look at the letter that the Senate majority leader sent to the president with 35 of his colleagues, I think there's every indication that Congress wants to get into the details of this. And then you're going to have a change of administrations in Mexico.

Overall, I think we are actually closer to the starting line than we are to the finish line. I wouldn't want the administration to start spiking the football. There's more work to do, but this is actually encouraging.

INGRAHAM: Yes, I mean, Sean, Congressman Duffy, this is something that the left, never Trump, they were all against it. Chamber of Commerce never wanted this. They said it was never going to happen. It is going to happen. I will count my chickens. It is going to happen and it's probably going to happen next week. And no one thought Trump could do it. No one thought Trump could do it. Your reaction tonight.

REP. SEAN DUFFY, (R) WISCONSIN: They had no faith in a great negotiator, Donald Trump. Let's be clear what's happening, Laura. When Donald Trump engaged Mexico, they recognized that there was some unfair practices between the two countries. They sat down and they worked them out with us, and it's a winner for both of us, but it's a winner for the American worker. From all my contacts inside the administration, the Canadians, they've been really hard to deal with. They're using America as a piggy bank, as Donald Trump will say, and they want to keep that piggy bank alive and well, sucking cash and jobs out of our country.

And Donald Trump, thank God he's standing up for the Wisconsin dairy. We want to sell our products all over the world. We can't sell them into Canada. They put a 200 to 300 percent tariff on our products. Laura, what happens if we said, OK, you put a 300 percent tariff on our milk. We'll put a 300 percent tariff on your autos that you're producing and trying to sell here. See how that goes over in Canada. Unfair.

INGRAHAM: Roger, what happened in this NAFTA set of talks is Canada was involved for almost the entire last year except for the last two months, because then they thought, oh, they're never going to agree, Mexico and the United States. Then we'll stand with Mexico against the United States and we'll get more out of it. Lo and behold, Mexico struck a deal with the United States and Canada was odd man out.

So Freeland flies in at the last minute and says, OK, maybe we can work something out. But that was a brilliant move. I think they underestimated the strength of the relationship forged by Bob Lighthizer, Jared Kushner, the entire U.S. TR team. These guys have been working around the clock, literally around the clock over the last 10 days. And I don't think people fully understood the strength of this new relationship with Mexico, presidential tweets notwithstanding.

FISK: Well, I think it's a great indication that the president should be able to rely on some of the experts he has. And I hope he starts to do that in some of the other challenges that he has on his plate. The issues with Mexico, some of the progress that was made with the auto parts and where the assembly points are located and things like that I think are great. I think you have to agree, there's still more work to be done. This is not the end of the whole process.

DUFFY: The left wants us to look to the globalists that were there before for their expertise. Donald Trump has a great gut himself, but we want those who are going to negotiation for America, for American dairy, for American manufacturers.

INGRAHAM: Guys, thank you so much. We're out of time, but fantastic conversation. We're going to be right back.

INGRAHAM: That's all the time we have tonight. I want to give a big thanks to a team out here in our Chicago bureau who helped get together the show over the last few days. It was a Herculean effort. And don't forget to tweet me @IngrahamAngle. Have a wonderful Labor Day weekend, and be sure to watch a special addition of THE INGRAHAM ANGLE on Labor Day. It's the best of "Seen and Unseen" with my partner in crime, Raymond Arroyo.

And until then, have a wonderful weekend, fly your flag, hang out with your family and friends. Up next, Shannon Bream. Goodnight form Chicago.

And I think this is part of the reason. Even if it's not intended to be disrespectful to the military, a lot of military veterans do feel that way. And I think that ends up hurting the whole experience for just a lot of folks.

ANTJUAN SEAWRIGHT, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Well, Laura, a couple things. I think sometimes what gets lost in the conversation is why this even started. This started because Kaepernick felt like black and brown people were mistreated at the hands of law enforcement. That's number one.

Number two, when you look at polls, and I'll take this scenario or any other scenario where people are being surveyed, it's all about how the question is asked, who is doing the asking, and how the question is being framed. But if you look at the NFL and you look at the bottom line, their revenue numbers, their revenue increased by five percent last year, not to mention the $50 million Amazon deal for streaming that was signed.

And so while these people may say they may not agree with the protests, I tend to believe that they still will watch the NFL. And football, like any other sport, is one of the very few things that most people, Democrats, Republicans, black or white, rich or poor, agree on. I just hate it's turned into a political football, no pun intended.

INGRAHAM: Yes, well, Kevin, I don't think anyone is trying to make it political. I think people --

SEAWRIGHT: Well, the president is, Laura.

INGRAHAM: Well, I think the president is standing up for what he believes in, which is just like the folks who are kneeling. They're kneeling for what they believe in, and the president is standing up for what he believes in. You can't have it one way and say this whole side gets to do this when the president can't talk about what he believes. Kevin, your thoughts on this?

KEVIN JACKSON: As Jerry Glanville said one time, NFL is going to stand for "Not For Long." He can quote all the numbers and statics he wants. The NFL is in triage. And I don't know why they're on this self-defeating path, but they like being on it. And it reminds me of what the Democrats are doing in going against Donald Trump in many ways.

SEAWRIGHT: Here we go.

JACKSON: At the end of the day -- yes, here we go. You're exactly right. Here we go. When you look at what's going on with what Donald Trump is standing up, the flag, he's standing up for veterans. By the way, he's also standing up for police. I've got a film coming out called "Bleeding Blue," and one of police in there says, hey, when something happens in your neighborhood, are you going to call a cop or are you going to call Colin Kaepernick? And he's exactly right. The police are going to have to do their jobs, and Colin Kaepernick, whether he likes it or not, he started a trend. And, Laura, I don't know what the statistics are, but I'll tell you, the overwhelming number of Americans believe in the flag, believe in the Anthem, believe in standing for it, and believe in the military, and believe in the police.

SEAWRIGHT: You can take a knee in protest but also stand up for believing in America and everything she stands for.

JACKSON: Take a knee for the people killed in Chicago.

SEAWRIGHT: Again, I'll say, you can focus on why this even started, the fact that African-American, black and brown people are five times more likely to be mishandled or killed at the hands of law enforcement. This is why that started. And so while you can see these people are not pro- America, look, my father served in the military. My father served so that these players would have the right to take their knee.

JACKSON: More black people are killed by other black people than cops. And you can argue this as much as you want. Randy Moss wore a tie to get inducted into the NFL Hall of Fame and it had 12 black people's names on it that expanded over a decade. This idea that cops are out hunting and killing black people is ridiculous.

SEAWRIGHT: No one ever said they were out hunting and killing black people. I said they were mishandled at the hands of law enforcement. Statistics will prove that to be true.

INGRAHAM: We've got to move on. We've got other topics we want to hit while I have you both here. So I want to get your reaction to this. Last night CNN's Don Lemon took a pretty nasty shot at Kanye West over Kanye's support for President Trump. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR: It's like a word salad where you realize that Kanye West, entitled to his own opinion, but is not very bright and not very -- when it comes -- I'm talking about this position, not overall, but when it comes to these issues, he's not clued in. He needs to read about it before he speaks about it. I'm not saying he's not a bright person. I take that back. That's not what I meant. But when it comes to this particular issue, he needs to look at a book, read some history, and understand what he's talking about.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: That's pretty condescending coming from Don Lemon, who himself has had a few wobbly moments. Let's watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I love you, too, but we really don't need to see what's about to happen here. I love you, Don. No, keep it closed. OK, I'm cutting you off after this one. Should I cut him off?

DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR: A lot of people have been asking about that, about black holes and on and on and on, and all of these conspiracy theories. Let's look at this. Noah says, "What else can you think about? Black hole? Bermuda Triangle." And then Deji says "Just like the movie "Lost?" And of course it's also referencing "The Twilight Zone," which has a very similar plot. That's what people are saying. I know it's preposterous. But is it preposterous?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: He was talking in that last sound bite about the Malaysian jet that disappeared, crashed, but could have been pulled up by a black hole. I mean, I guess. I'm being charitable tonight. I guess.

JACKSON: You don't have to have Don Lemon being drunk to showcase his lunacy. Just watch his program any night.

SEAWRIGHT: Because you don't agree with him.

JACKSON: No. I don't agree with you, but you're sitting here and I'm not interrupting you. Look, at the end of the day, when you look at what he said about Kanye West, he's trying to correct a grown man who dare have an opinion that differs from his. And, oh, by the way, Donald Lemon, Kanye happens to be right. There are many reasons for us to be looking at Donald Trump through the prism, it certainly is black folks, to be looking to Donald Trump as a person who's done a lot more for blacks than Barack Obama.

SEAWRIGHT: Oh, Jesus Christ, man.

JACKSON: And people don't want to admit this. And for Don Lemon and this particular gentleman to keep talking about Donald Trump as if he's some bad guy, or Kanye West who is bringing out what we're calling the Kanye effect is ridiculous. More black people are waking up because of Kanye West and his comments, because they're tired of being demonized, because --

INGRAHAM: All right, let's go to Antjuan. Antjuan?

SEAWRIGHT: Laura, that sounds all good. What Don Lemon did -- he corrected his statement.

INGRAHAM: Antjuan, Antjuan.

JACKSON: I know, but I'm going to interrupt him like he did me, Laura.

SEAWRIGHT: What Don Lemon corrected was Kaney's position, and Kanye even apologized and walked it back, his comment about enslavement a couple of days ago on a national radio show because he was actually wrong. And I appreciate him taking his comments back.

JACKSON: He wasn't wrong.

SEAWRIGHT: Look, I am not for criticizing someone for having an opinion because we all have one.

JACKSON: Yes, you are.

INGRAHAM: Yes, why not?

SEAWRIGHT: Make sure when you speak of a certain instance, make sure that the facts are very, very clear. And I'm glad that Kanye West was able to be man enough to walk back his comments.

INGRAHAM: Guys, we've got to roll. All right, we've got to roll, guys. Thanks so much for joining us tonight.

I have a question, though. Is President Trump about to prove his naysayers wrong and score a huge victory for America? Well, how about in trade? Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

INGRAHAM: Canada feeling the heat from President Trump over a new trade deal. Tensions spilled out in the public view throughout the day under a looming deadline. Take a listen to Canada's minister of foreign affairs.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHRYSTIA FREELAND, CANADIAN MINISTER OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS: We are committed to speaking for Canada to a deal which is a good deal for Canada, not just any deal. We are very good as Canadians at finding win-win compromises. At the end of the day, though, we are only going to sign a deal that's good for Canada.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: Now, a final agreement was not yet inked, reached today. But talks are set to resume next Wednesday. And my sources are telling me they're very close.

Joining us now to analyze is Wisconsin Republican Sean Duffy, along with Democratic strategist Roger Risk. Great to see you both. Roger, let's start with you. This issue of trade is something I've been writing about for, I don't know, about 20 years. And Bob Lighthizer, Jared Kushner, Luis Videgaray who was on our show exclusively on Monday night, and Freeland were all behind closed doors today. They're hammering this out. It's very complicated. The agricultural subsidies that Canada gives, especially to its dairy farmers, are incredibly important to Quebec. And that's a sticking point. But my sources are telling me they're extremely close. And no one wants Canada to walk away from the table. Canada doesn't and obviously the administration doesn't. Your reaction tonight?

ROGER FISK, FORMER OBAMA ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: I think it's almost the tale of two trade talks. I find some encouraging elements to how the administration has conducted itself with the Mexican set of the trade talks. That's been more sober, more process-driven. They've been working on it for a year. I hope that the success of that as we move forward starts to guide how the president views the resources around him, starts to maybe trust in some of the professionals that are there to help him.

The Canadian discussion is obviously much more accelerated and I think is going to take more time maybe than what we think right now. And then there's other factors that are going to make this more difficult as we go ahead. We have the 90-day window with Congress. If you look at the letter that the Senate majority leader sent to the president with 35 of his colleagues, I think there's every indication that Congress wants to get into the details of this. And then you're going to have a change of administrations in Mexico.

Overall, I think we are actually closer to the starting line than we are to the finish line. I wouldn't want the administration to start spiking the football. There's more work to do, but this is actually encouraging.

INGRAHAM: Yes, I mean, Sean, Congressman Duffy, this is something that the left, never Trump, they were all against it. Chamber of Commerce never wanted this. They said it was never going to happen. It is going to happen. I will count my chickens. It is going to happen and it's probably going to happen next week. And no one thought Trump could do it. No one thought Trump could do it. Your reaction tonight.

REP. SEAN DUFFY, (R) WISCONSIN: They had no faith in a great negotiator, Donald Trump. Let's be clear what's happening, Laura. When Donald Trump engaged Mexico, they recognized that there was some unfair practices between the two countries. They sat down and they worked them out with us, and it's a winner for both of us, but it's a winner for the American worker. From all my contacts inside the administration, the Canadians, they've been really hard to deal with. They're using America as a piggy bank, as Donald Trump will say, and they want to keep that piggy bank alive and well, sucking cash and jobs out of our country.

And Donald Trump, thank God he's standing up for the Wisconsin dairy. We want to sell our products all over the world. We can't sell them into Canada. They put a 200 to 300 percent tariff on our products. Laura, what happens if we said, OK, you put a 300 percent tariff on our milk. We'll put a 300 percent tariff on your autos that you're producing and trying to sell here. See how that goes over in Canada. Unfair.

INGRAHAM: Roger, what happened in this NAFTA set of talks is Canada was involved for almost the entire last year except for the last two months, because then they thought, oh, they're never going to agree, Mexico and the United States. Then we'll stand with Mexico against the United States and we'll get more out of it. Lo and behold, Mexico struck a deal with the United States and Canada was odd man out.

So Freeland flies in at the last minute and says, OK, maybe we can work something out. But that was a brilliant move. I think they underestimated the strength of the relationship forged by Bob Lighthizer, Jared Kushner, the entire U.S. TR team. These guys have been working around the clock, literally around the clock over the last 10 days. And I don't think people fully understood the strength of this new relationship with Mexico, presidential tweets notwithstanding.

FISK: Well, I think it's a great indication that the president should be able to rely on some of the experts he has. And I hope he starts to do that in some of the other challenges that he has on his plate. The issues with Mexico, some of the progress that was made with the auto parts and where the assembly points are located and things like that I think are great. I think you have to agree, there's still more work to be done. This is not the end of the whole process.

DUFFY: The left wants us to look to the globalists that were there before for their expertise. Donald Trump has a great gut himself, but we want those who are going to negotiation for America, for American dairy, for American manufacturers.

INGRAHAM: Guys, thank you so much. We're out of time, but fantastic conversation. We're going to be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

INGRAHAM: That's all the time we have tonight. I want to give a big thanks to a team out here in our Chicago bureau who helped get together the show over the last few days. It was a Herculean effort. And don't forget to tweet me @IngrahamAngle. Have a wonderful Labor Day weekend, and be sure to watch a special addition of THE INGRAHAM ANGLE on Labor Day. It's the best of "Seen and Unseen" with my partner in crime, Raymond Arroyo.

And until then, have a wonderful weekend, fly your flag, hang out with your family and friends. Up next, Shannon Bream. Goodnight form Chicago.

END

urn:contentItem:5VP1-FVW1-JBSW-72XD-00000-00CNN Town Hall with Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-MA)2019-03-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:00ZLexisNexisCNN Town Hall with Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-MA)

Participants: Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-MA); Jake Tapper, CNN Host

Time: 21:00:00

Date: 2019-03-18

TAPPER: Good evening from Jackson, Mississippi, and welcome to a CNN Democratic presidential candidate town hall with Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts. I'm Jake Tapper.

(APPLAUSE)

We are live at Jackson State University, a historically black university founded in 1877 for the first major Democratic 2020 event in the state of Mississippi. We're here with Senator Warren, a former special needs teacher and law professor who made her name fighting the big banks. If elected, she would make history as the first female president of the United States of America.

Tonight, Senator Warren will take questions from Democrats and independents who say they plan to participate in the Democratic primaries and caucuses. Please welcome Senator Elizabeth Warren.

(APPLAUSE)

WARREN: Hey, Jake.

TAPPER: How are you? Good to see you.

WARREN: Good to see you.

TAPPER: Have a seat.

(APPLAUSE)

WARREN: Oh, this is fun.

TAPPER: So before we begin, you're a former law professor. Feel good to be back on a campus?

WARREN: Oh, it always feels good to be back on a campus. Absolutely.

TAPPER: Which is more fun, teaching law students, teaching on a campus, or working with senators in the U.S. Senate?

WARREN: Oh, teaching. Are you kidding?

(LAUGHTER)

Much more fun.

TAPPER: I thought you might give that answer.

WARREN: That's right.

TAPPER: Let's start with our first town hall question. The first one comes from Christopher Lane. He's a doctoral candidate in public health here at Jackson State University. Christopher?

QUESTION: Good evening, Senator Warren. My question is, Mississippi is a deeply red state and one of the poorest states in the country, yet many white poor and working-class citizens continue to vote against their economic interests. What message, if any, do you have that may resonate with them that may encourage them to vote for you?

WARREN: So, thank you for the question, Christopher. Look, this is how I see it. Washington is working great, it's working fabulously for giant drug companies. It's just not working for people who are trying to get a prescription filled.

(APPLAUSE)

It's working great for big oil companies that want to drill everywhere. It's just not working for people who see climate change bearing down upon us.

(APPLAUSE)

It's working great for giant financial institutions and for payday lenders. It's just not working great for people who are living paycheck to paycheck.

(APPLAUSE)

I'm tired of a Washington that works for the rich and the powerful. I want a Washington that works for the rest of America. That's why I'm in this fight.

(APPLAUSE)

And I believe on that, that Democrats, independents, and Republicans, they know a scam when they see it. And they see a Washington working for those guys. I think they're ready to get in the fight and get a Washington and a country that works for the rest of America. Thank you. Thank you.

TAPPER: So our next -- our next questioner is Khalita Hicks. She's a supporter of yours and a Spanish language translator from Jackson. Khalita?

WARREN: Hi, Khalita.

QUESTION: Good evening. Since the election of Donald Trump, the number of hate crimes has increased and white supremacists have become more emboldened online and in public. What are your plans to unite the country?

WARREN: Oh, good. Thank you for that question. You know, it starts with the fact that we've got to recognize the threat posed by white nationalism. White supremacists pose a threat to the United States like any other terrorist group, like ISIS, like Al Qaida.

And leadership starts at the top. And that means you've got to call it out.

(APPLAUSE)

No sitting by. And then when you call it out, as president of the United States, you've got to use the tools available to you. And that means get the Justice Department when they break the law to go after them with full prosecution. That's what I can do. Thank you.

(APPLAUSE)

Thank you. Good question.

TAPPER: Our next question comes from Georgia Cohran. She's a graduate student here at Jackson State University. Georgia?

WARREN: Hi, Georgia.

QUESTION: Hi, thank you, Senator Warren, for taking my question.

TAPPER: Got to hold the mike up there.

QUESTION: Thank you so much for taking my question. I am an African-American female with -- I'm an African-American female with five beautiful adult children and 10 grandchildren.

WARREN: Oh, Georgia, count your blessings every day.

(LAUGHTER)

QUESTION: Please, please, describe to me what a public apology to -- for 400 years of free labor...

WARREN: Yeah.

QUESTION: ... in the South, especially Mississippi, will look like in the African American community in the new election.

WARREN: All right, thank you, Georgia.

QUESTION: In the new administration.

WARREN: Thank you.

(APPLAUSE)

So, America was founded on principles of liberty and freedom, and on the backs of slave labor. This is a stain on America, and we're not going to fix that, we're not going to change that until we address it head on, directly.

(APPLAUSE)

And make no mistake: It's not just the original founding. It's what's happened generation after generation. The impact of discrimination handed down from one to the next means that today in America, because of housing discrimination, because of employment discrimination, we live in a world where for the average white family has $100, the average black family has about $5.

So I believe it's time to start the national full-blown conversation about reparations in this country.

(APPLAUSE)

And that means I support the bill in the House to appoint a congressional panel of experts, of people who are studying this, who talk about different ways we may be able to do it, and to make a report back to Congress so that we can as a nation do what's right and begin to heal. Thank you. Thank you.

(APPLAUSE)

TAPPER: Senator, if I could just follow up on -- if I could just follow up on Georgia's question, you've said you're open to a conversation about reparations to the descendants of slaves and also to Native Americans, you also said. Might that include direct payments, direct financial transfer of money?

WARREN: So there are a lot of ways to think about how reparations should be formed. And I noticed, Georgia's question actually started with just the frame of an apology, right, with the frame of a national recognition.

We have a lot of experts around the country, a lot of activists who have a whole lot of different approaches to it. And I think the best we can do right now -- I love the idea of this congressional commission. Let's bring people together and let's open that conversation as Americans. Let's see what ideas people want to put on the table, and let's talk them through, because I got to tell you, ignoring the problem is not working.

(APPLAUSE)

TAPPER: Let me bring in Jay Kucia. He's a supporter of yours, as well. He's a student who founded a labor rights group at the University of Mississippi Law School. That's in Oxford, I believe.

WARREN: Right.

TAPPER: He has a question about Medicare for all. Jay?

WARREN: All right.

QUESTION: Senator Warren, thank you so much for being here this evening and your tireless advocacy for universal health care. As a supporter of universal health care and an advocate for organized labor, I do worry about the current bills' elimination of private health insurance...

WARREN: Oh, yeah.

QUESTION: ... that would eliminate the private health employer-based plans that so many unions have advocated for. Can you explain how Medicare for all would be better for workers than simply improving the Affordable Care Act?

WARREN: OK, so it's a good question. Let's start with our statement that we should make every time we start to talk about changes in our health care, and that is health care is a basic human right and we fight for basic human rights.

(APPLAUSE)

And then let's put these in order, because I appreciate that your question starts with the Affordable Care Act. Let's all remember when we're talking about what's possible, let's start where we are and the difference between Democrats and Republicans.

Right now, Democrats are trying to figure out how to expand health care coverage at the lowest possible cost so everybody is covered. Republicans right this minute are out there trying to repeal the Affordable Care Act. They've got a lawsuit pending down in Texas where they're trying to roll it back. What they couldn't do with a vote, they're trying to do with the courts. HHS every day is doing what they can to undermine the Affordable Care Act.

So when we're talking about health care in America right now, the first thing we need to be talking about is defend the Affordable Care Act, protection under the Affordable Care Act.

(APPLAUSE)

Then part two. Let's make the improvements that are what I think of as low-hanging fruit. For example, let's bring down the cost of prescription drugs all across this country.

(APPLAUSE)

We got lots of ways we can do that. We can import drugs from Canada where the safety standards are the same. That would cut costs dramatically. We can negotiate the prices under Medicare. That would cut costs dramatically.

And I've got a proposal to help bring down the cost on generic drugs, which could be about 90 percent of all prescriptions. So let's get those costs down.

And then you know what you're going to hear from a consumer advocate, and that is we need to hold insurance companies accountable. And that means no tricking and trapping people on those insurance contracts.

(APPLAUSE)

And then when we talk about Medicare for all, there are a lot of different pathways. What we're all looking for is the lowest cost way to make sure everybody gets covered. And some folks are talking about let's start lowering the age, maybe bring it down to 60, 55, 50. That helps cover people who are most at risk and can be helpful, for example, to the labor's plans.

Some people say, do it the other way. Let's bring it up from -- everybody under 30 gets covered by Medicare. Others say let employees be able to buy into the Medicare plans. Others say let's let employees buy into the Medicare plans.

For me, what's key is we get everybody at the table on this, that labor is at the table, that people who have to buy on their own, everybody comes to the table together. And we figure out how to do Medicare for all in a way that makes sure that we're going to get 100 percent coverage in this country at the lowest possible cost for everyone. That's our job.

(APPLAUSE)

You like that?

TAPPER: If I could just follow up a little on Jay's question, so you are a co-sponsor of Senator Bernie Sanders' Medicare for all bill, and I understand there are a lot of different paths to universal coverage, but his bill that you've co-sponsored would essentially eliminate private insurance. Is that something you could support?

WARREN: He's got a runway for that. I think we get everybody together. And that's what it is, we'll decide. I've also co-sponsored other bills, including expanding Medicaid as another approach that we use. But what's really important to me about this is we never lose sight of what the center is, because the center is about making sure that every single person in this country gets the coverage they need and that it's at a price that they can afford. We start with our values, we'll get to the right place.
